Please note that I'm not that very good at reviews.
I must first state that this is outside my prefered genres of anime, which is quite a feat, since I'm quite picky when it comes to slice-of-life/sports anime.
I actually rather enjoy this. To such an extreme that I would on the edge of my seat while watching, getting shivers and feeling a buzz I usually only get when watching horror/thriller anime. I was hooked right from the beginning, intriged right to the end.
*The story at first is a tad confusing, but after watching Higurashi, I can usually swallow any beginnings before ditching it. But, as itprogressed, I found myself caught up with the story, wanting to know more if I could. Even now when I'm finished, I am itchin to go read the manga cause I don't want it to end.


*I found the art just stunning, it had a somewhat unique feel to it and it's rather catching at certain moments. I was always focused on the art and the style and the color, almost everything while watching.


*I liked the music that played, in the openings and the endings as well as during the anime, but, I felt that it overstood most of the story as well as characters. 


*I like their personalities a lot and not every person is the same, everyone was different, even though you'd think some where similar, you'd later find out that they were so far from the truth. I enjoyed watching Kuroko, he has such an interesting personality that you just can't help but like him in a way, as well as Kagami and the other Generation of Miracles (the three that actually show up here). 


*I enjoyed the anime quite a bit, which is a slight shock, since this is so out of my genre as far as it can get. I was always glued to the screen and would always be annoyed when I had to go to bed or school, sometimes ending up dreaming the anime just cause I loved it so much.


*Overall, it was a rather interesting anime and I highly recommend it. This is something that will keep you hooked and entertained to no end. But, that was one down point, it's unfinished. It may say complete but you can tell that there is much story to be told, but I guess it isn't so bad, since the manga is out there to be read. I just wish that they pick this up again, cause I would to see some more.


Don't get mad at me if it's a bad review, I tried to keep all spoilers out but as detailed as possible. Anyway, I really enjoyed the anime ^^ Hope others would think so as well.

First review, might as well do it for my favorite anime. 
I'm gonna start off by saying I don't watch sports anime or just sports in general. This is my first sports anime ever. And I love it. The first episode got me hooked. I don't remember why I clicked on it. All I know is I'm extremely glad I did. The art is amazing, the story is addictive, and let's face it the characters are hot. There isn't a reason you shouldn't give it a shot. Watch the first episode and then if you don't like it, drop it. You have nothing to loseby giving Kuroko no Basket a chance. \n\n
I give it a 10 out 10.

Before I gave this show a chance, I used to think that it was not the show for me. Firstly - I was not all that into basketball; second - the genre tags did not interest me one bit. If you were like me and grew up watching shows like "Shakugan no Shana", or "Angel Beats", you would probably share my opinion. Right now, I am up to episode 6. It is 2AM and I have my first day back of school tomorrow, but I simply can't stop watching. Here is why:
Many Animes tend to make the main character overpowered, and exaggerate their brute strength(or miraculously give them the power to 'believe', as to magically give them a boost of strength so they can overcome their struggles) so they can gain admiration from the show's viewers. This is not the case in "Kuroko no Basket". The main character - Kuroko - in contrast, is extremely weak compared to the other characters in the series (arguably the weakest). However, that does not make him useless. Instead of making the main character a complete powerhouse, Kuroko is more of an accessory - a utility - which in this case really makes this Anime shine. This simple detail makes us realise what the concept of 'teamwork' really means in Basketball (and other sports, as well).\n\n
Being only 1/4 my way through the series, I do not have too much to write - i might add more later on. However, I believe that you should give Kuroko no Basket a shot (no pun intended), even if you think it's not for you. I, myself, got hooked on the first episode.

Let me begin by saying I knew nothing about basketball prior to watching this, I didn't know what a point guard was, what kind of shots are considered three pointers, etc. However, while I was watching some anime on animewaffles I noticed people in the chat talking about kuroko no basket and how amazing it was. I decided to look it up on MAL only to find out it was ranked pretty high and was a sports anime, a genre that I always wanted to give try. At first I wasn't expecting anything to exciting and fun to watch, I mean how could they makean ordinary sport become exciting? However, this anime succeeded in making basketball interesting and unique to have me marathon the entire first season within a day. The flashy passes, the dunks, and the jaw dropping shots being made was enough to get me hooked. Furthermore, there were five special players who each have their own special abilities, as these characters are revealed as the season goes on further contributed to the addiction I had with this series. There was a sixth player who also had a special ability that I will mention later in the review. I will refrain from specifying what these "special abilities" are in my review specifically to avoid any spoilers, so expect seeing this term being used a lot. However, let me first address some falsely stated criticism before doing so: 


A common critique is that Kuroko no basket goes over the top with these special skills that the characters have when playing basketball, and makes the game play look incredibly unrealistic. Its important to realize that this is an anime, of course its gonna be unrealistic. Look at one piece for example its about pirates with devil fruit abilities that cause ordinary humans to gain unrealistic powers, and swordsmen who have tornadoes flying out of their swords, while in reality we see pirates as people with eye patches and guns killing people for treasure. Despite this, one piece is incredibly popular and not critiqued at all for having this trait. If you want to watch realistic anime you are going to have a bad time especially for sports anime which would be pretty boring if they were to be realistic since there is already a channel for realistic basketball and other sports, ESPN.


Another common critique this anime receives is that its very yaoi like. This is not true however as the anime mainly focuses on its story of the main characters Kuroko and Kagami developing their basketball skills to take on the generation of miracles and ultimately become the best basketball team in Japan. While there is a little of man-service here and there it does not affect the overall story of the anime as a whole and it isn't present in every episode. Only the filler episodes contain yaoi but even then its pretty moderate. 


Story: 9/10

There was a middle school known as  Teiko Junior High which consisted of a legendary basketball team which consisted of five players known as the generation of miracles.This team dominated every competition they came across.  Each of these players had their own unique skill and an astonishing amount of talent. When their middle school days were over, the generation of miracles went to different high schools, each of which were well known for basketball. However, there was sixth member of the generation of miracles ,Kuroko who specialized in passing, joined the Serin basketball team which was not as well known as the other high schools the other members of the generation of miracles went to. It was at this high school that Kuroko met Kagami, a  player who transferred from America with lots of talent that haven't yet emerged. Together, Kagami and Kuroko plan to defeat the generation of miracles and become the best Basketball team in Japan.


Overall, the story was not to complex and did not leave the viewer to think and  was really easy to understand. I was able to watch it without putting much thought into it. It also didn't have much filler, and the filler is when the yaoi scenes seem to come in so you could skip them without missing much of the main plot. The pacing of this series was great, I found myself watching one episode after another and eventually watched the whole series in one day. However, the predictability of who would win the match disappointed me a little but that doesn't take away from the fact that the show was enjoyable to watch. In fact, I think the unique skill that each of the main characters possess make the games more interesting to watch, especially if the viewer has a disliking to realistic basketball. 


Art/animation: 9/10

Not that bad, but not a masterpiece either. Some episodes had better animation than others but that may have been due to budget. At times some of the passes and shots being made felt unnatural almost as if they didn't draw enough frames. However, it compassionates this flaw with close ups of shots, dunks, and steals all of which contribute to the thrill and overall excitement of the viewer. However, the close ups of the faces of almost everyone playing a match each time someone made a shot was unnecessary and at times annoying. However, considering the budget, the animation/art was not too bad and is one of the better sports anime out there.


Sound: 10/10

The actual soundtrack may be  where Kuroko no Basket shines. It fits perfectly with the scenes. In fact, the sound enhances the thrills felt with each scene. It also enhances the atmosphere and tension the players feel during a match, especially the heavy guitar playing tracks that come in whenever something epic happens such as an epic block or pass that  seemed to be impossible at first. The sound is acts as a great contribution factor to the adrenaline rush and thrill the viewer feels during these intense, epic moments.  The voice acting was great as well, though I don't think I ever saw an anime where the sub was bad. Overall, the sound in this anime was great overall. 


Character: 9/10

The development we see in the two main characters(Kuroko/Kagami) in this series is one of the elements that makes this anime addicting. You want to keep watching this series because you want to see what kind of special technique Kuroko and Kagami will develop next. The reveal of each member of the generation of miracles and their abilities as they played a match against Serin was also what made me kept watching. However, there are a handful of players on Serin's team that get no back story or much screen time which was a real disappointment but they still fulfilled their roles. 


Enjoyment: 10/10

Like I said before, I wasn't expecting to become hooked to this show as I did considering my lack of knowledge of regular basketball. Needless to say, this anime was pretty enjoyable. While it did have its flaws, with the close-ups on the characters faces each time someone made a shot,  and didn't give as much of a thrill as some other anime (Monster, Death Note,) it managed to have me marathon it through its use of unrealistic shots and other elements that made watching this type of basketball more enjoyable. It even got me to look up more about basketball as well. In short, if you are looking for a sports anime to watch or just want to watch a simple yet enjoyable anime, Kuroko no Basket is the anime for you.

Kuroko no Basket
Review By: John Fragglepuss Evans
Kuroko no Basket combines basketball with anime in such a good way. The basics of basketball are there, but they are combined with the action and drama that anime utilizes so well. The dunks are intense, the passes are intense and they use beams of light to show just how amazing the passes truly are. Kuroko and Kagami remind me of the old NBA combo of John Stockton and Karl Malone, one with finesse and the other with raw power. In true sports anime fashion, the matches are all important and all last several episodes while the drama andintensity unfold.


You might enjoy this if: You are a sports anime veteran or even if you are a sports anime rookie.


You might not like it if: Over dramatized motions and slow-motion sweat is too much for you.


Note to the Viewer: Be prepared to get sucked into the story and watch a season in a day.

One of the mangas or animes that I will never get tired of re-reading or re-watching also the one that I remember almost everything from the manga and anime.
Art: The art for me is outstanding and the animation is flawless. The setting, plot and character concepts or let us say everything is well played in this show. The ingredients are nearly perfect that will always leave you wanting more. Well for a manga reader like me I would say the anime exceeded my expectations since it made me like the show and finish it. That is for someone like me who would choose manga anyday of my life than anime. It is really that good to be honest!


Sound: I recommend you to use earphones when watching especially a match episode and I'll tell you you're like inside of the court watching the game. Openings and endings are cool too. The opening song Can't Do It  is so cool, I've never seen such timing and the awesomeness of the closing song Fantastic Tune.


Character: Probably the only show that I will give a 10. I don't know how will I put to words of how awesome the characters in this show are. The intro is awesome and gave me goosebumps it is where "Kiseki no Sedai or The Generation of Miracles" is being explained. It is probably is the biggest thing that hit me since it reminded me the days when I'm still an athlete. Another thing that amazes me is also the colors of the rainbow concept, composed of a red, yellow, green, blue, violet and light blue haired characters. It is the genius concept made by the author having their hair color different from each other to symbolize their uniqueness as prodigies of basketball of their generation that only happens once every century.


Enjoyment: Oh for the love of basketball! Thank heavens this is finally here after how many years of waiting. Each match episode is breathtaking and mind-blowing but the anime-ish is still there like the clock will stop if a character is talking in the middle of the game. If you used to play before, you will really enjoy this show because you can relate seventy to eighty percent of each episode.


Overall: 


This show can embrace my 9. The base of story talks about the coincidence happened in middle school. Four basketball prodigies of the same age having to enter the same basketball club at the same time and at the same perfect moment. "Nothing but a sweet coincidence" as the author have said. Followed also by a freshman who does not even know the basics but loves playing basketball and what completes the group is the one who's already bored because he excels at any sports he played and have found basketball as the only sport that he can't ace.


The main story is the reunion of each of the prodigy with their respective basketball teams having to do the vow they made before graduation to face each other someday together with each other's team. This is not just purely basketball, there is so much more!


If you happen to play in a team before, you will experience the feelings of being happy, sad and excited. The show will teach you moral lessons (e.g. being attentive, flexible, trusting your companions, never give up, don't lose hope and the most important: talent is not given it is how bad you want to achieve your goal) 


({ This is the most nostalgic anime and manga that I've ever read and watched because it really reminds me of what I was back then. }]

Kuroko no Basuke is a lot more epic than realistic. Which is all the better, in my opinion, because it makes for a great accessible sports anime. I wasn’t expecting to enjoy this genre, yet here I am shipping a basketball related anime! Honestly, the pacing is so good it’s hard not to get completely hooked. With its strong themes of perseverance, ambition and self-improvement, I think this anime can not only please sports anime fans, but also just about any shonen fan. Just you watch it!
Story : 9
Most episodes end on a cliffhanger that really makes you want to watch the next episode, soI ended up watching them all in a very short period of time. I don’t play basketball, but the anime is so well executed that the matches are very exciting to watch. It feels like a good action shonen, where the protagonists advance to face stronger opponents in epic battles, but it is easier to relate to since it’s about a real sport. It really motivates you to go out there and be a motivated warrior, no matter what sport you play.


Characters : 9

The characters are interesting enough. There are plenty of likable characters, a succession of prodigies with secret abilities, some mysterious villains and other passionate sportspeople. It’s especially good that they have a past story to link them all, allowing for great character development. Also, the way they are slowly introduced throughout the story builds awesome suspense.


Art : 8

The animation during the games is outstanding, with fluid movements and impressive plays. For the ladies out there, it is worth mentioning that this anime features its fair share of nicely drawn muscled young men. It’s hot, you know, even if it’s just a drawing. But don’t worry guys, this anime takes sport seriously, the focus is really on competition and testosterone-driven fights.


Sound : 8

The opening and ending songs were nice to listen to. For the rest, I was too caught up in the games to notice the background music during the episodes. I think it shows that the soundtrack really blends in with the series. Good music helps build tension without causing distraction. The seyus did a great job too.


Enjoyment : 10

I thoroughly enjoyed this series from beginning to end. It was suspenseful and intriguing all along and the matches were amazing to watch. It seems like they put a lot of thought in how they would divide the story into episodes, making sure each episode has something interesting to offer and is well balanced between action, character development, mystery and even comedy. There is always just the right amount of comic relief to highlight the tensed moments of the series.

For the first time I have watched a pure sports anime and it surprised me how non over the top it was.
Kuroko is one hell of a dude in my book, he hos the argo of a knife wielder in army of two and he can alter the course of a  pass like I can type out this probably really bad review, like all the rest I have made. I haven't written a review here on MAL before, but his show exceeded my expectations so much that I decided I needed to write a review for those (like me for the longest time) who may be hesitant to watch this. 
First of all, it is NOT required that you like basketball to enjoy this series- that's a major point I want to get out there quickly, and is also a big reason I'm writing this review. I'm not a basketball fan myself, but the show does a great job of pulling the viewer in and making what is happening on-screen extremely entertaining regardless ofwhether you like basketball or not. So again, give this show a shot even if you're not a big basketball fan. I delayed trying it out for a long time because of this and once I finally watched it I couldn't believe what I had been missing out on.  The comedy, characters, soundtrack, and art and animation are all top-notch and will entertain you even if you don't particularly care for the basketball part of the story. Now, on to the specifics.


The characters are what make this show so great. All the characters who get significant screen time are sufficiently fleshed out. For such a large cast of characters (That is: Everybody from the "main" team that the story focuses on, and roughly a little less than a dozen characters from other teams), I was surprised at how each of them were so well developed and how they each had something unique about them. The characters are all so well developed and unique that it really didn't matter who was on-screen at the time, because it was guaranteed to be entertaining regardless. The show does a great job of giving all these quality characters a good amount of screen time each. This is not the kind of show where the MC hogs 80% of the screen time, and that really helps to develop each character and make the interactions between the different characters so great. Some of the best interactions between characters actually don't involve the MC at all, and yet, some of the best interactions DO involve the MC. There is a very good mixture of comedy, drama, and action, and each of the characters has something to contribute to that.


The soundtrack is the next thing that I would point out as being a major strong point of the show. All the songs are very catchy and they each do a great job of adding hype to a clutch moment or to add melancholy to a sad one. During the games, there is almost never a moment where there isn't background music. Some people may find this annoying, but I loved that about the show because it really added a sense of excitement to each of the games even when the teams are just going over strategies on the bench or a character is monologuing on the court. 


The art and animation are also very high-quality. The art isn't anything flashy but it looks good and the animation during some of the high-paced scenes on the court is very well done. I especially like the detail that went into characterizing certain characters through their facial expressions or their body movement. It did a lot for adding to that "unqiueness" I mentioned that they each have. Even the smallest details went into the animation to ensure that no two characters' bodies move the same on the court, which is a very cool detail when you consider that this is the case in real sports as well. 


The story is actually really good for a sports anime. The "Generation of Miracles" are a very solid group of antagonists for the main characters to have to try and overcome. Each characters' motivations and goals are reasonable and it's interesting to see how they try to achieve those goals. While it is a good story for a sports anime though, it is still a pretty typical story for a shounen. 


Overall, a really good series that can be enjoyed by anybody regardless of if they're a sports fan or not. Really good art/animation, great soundtrack, GREAT cast of characters, but suffers from the fact that the story is typical shounen. 


Recap: 

Story: 7

Art: 9

Sound: 10 (amazing soundtrack)

Characters: 10 (definitely the best part of the show)

Enjoyment: 10

Overall: 9

Are you looking for a sports anime that's coherent, realistic, and handles the sport it features properly? If yes, stay far away from Kuroko no Basket. On the other hand, if you are looking something that's flashy, cool, funny, and couldn't give any less of a shit about stuff like logic and plot execution, this anime is for you.
Kuroko no Basket suffers from a very wide variety of problems. Depending on how much these problems bother you personally, your enjoyment of this anime will be affected from a bit to a lot. The pacing is bad, the plot progression is arbitrarily forced, the characters tendto be lackluster (with some exceptions), it is completely unrealistic but pretends it isn't, which is annoying, it is utterly incoherent, and finally, it makes no fucking sense.


Despite everything mentioned above, I wouldn't say it's bad anime overall. Its main redeeming quality is that it is funny. When it tries to be funny, it usually succeeds. There are also occasions when it is unintentionally funny due to overflowing stupidity.


How much you are going to enjoy this anime depends a lot on how much you think about it. The more you think about it, the more it falls apart. But if you are just looking for mindless entertainment, this is a good fit. There's no shame in that.

"Why would I watch 5 high school boys run around and play basketball? How interesting can basketball REALLY be?" - Me, before watching Kuroko no Basket. First of all, I had no previous liking to basketball, so when my friend suggested this anime to me, I turned it down. With some pestering, I finally watched it and wow...
High school sports and borderline super powers, Kuroko no Basket has to now be one of my favorite animes. A series that consistently sticks to its story from the first episode to the last. I'm writing this review after finishing the 3rd season, so I hope to dodgeas much spoiler material I can but give you enough to watch the series.


The story starts where high school basketball team, Seirin, recruit some new players including 2 prodigies: Kagami Taiga and Tetsuya Kuroko. As you would expect, it revolves around this team playing basketball while facing numerous challenges along the way. The biggest challenge - the members of the generation of miracles. Beware, these guys play basketball at a whole new level of the game with skills that could be called super powers, Kuroko no Basket has to be the king of exaggeration when it comes to basketball abilities. Along with the game, the story (being a shonen anime) is also about friendship and overcoming obstacles through the power of it. For me, it has the perfect blend of drama, comedy, and action. The sort that is suitable for all ages and whether or not you're a fan of basketball.


The visuals are very good, from the vibrant colors to the angles used to show the game. I personally think the art style is perfect for this show and thankfully, it remains the same throughout the 3 seasons. The sound effects and soundtracks also compliment the visuals. You have the typical basketball sounds (bounces, net swishes, sneaker screeches etc.) and the BGM that suits the situation perfectly, immersing you into the moment.


There is so much diversity when it comes to characters. There are multiple teams you will come to know and most of them have a character or two you will become familiar with. The generation of miracles stand out from the rest in terms of uniqueness, but that doesn't overshadow the others. Each of these characters have a distinctive look to them, as well as personality and traits. Even when it comes down to playing styles! Of all the animes that I have seen, this one has to offer the largest variety of characters.


All of that taken in, I thoroughly enjoyed all 3 seasons. The first episode set the tone and I couldn't stop watching until I had finished the 2nd season (the 3rd wasn't released yet) and for the sake of keeping the momentum going between episodes, I let the 3rd season finish because I couldn't bear waiting another week to see what happens next. It was one of those ones I just wanted to watch as much as I could in one sitting.


I rated this season an overall of 10, purely because the concept was so unique and I was taken back by how entertaining they made basketball. I also questioned how long could they keep it up, I mean "how interesting can basketball REALLY be"? Well, they managed to keep it fresh through to the end and I would give it a collected rating of 9/10. That being somewhere in the better half of 9 too.


TL:DR - If you're looking for an easy to watch, entertaining shonen anime with great characters and a strong story line, then look no further. You don't even have to have extensive knowledge or be a fan of basketball to enjoy this one.


Reviewers message: This is my second review, I really hope this helps! Though I wrote exactly what came to mind, I know there are ways to improve my reviews, so feedback would be appreciated very much :) Thank you!

Kuroko no Basuke is a great anime, worth watching 100%. Honestly, for someone who never liked sports anime, I enjoyed it thoroughly as it had this mix of shounen with sports. It was pretty intense, the viewer constantly getting into it because of the non-stop action and those sick (in a good way) techniques the characters used. Compared to a normal basketball game, it was relatively more vivid and vibrant, without losing the realistic parts of the actual sport. 
As for the story line, in one word; amazing. On one hand lays the outstanding plot on the other, the deeper meaning, friendship and teamwork, akait wasn't just a bunch of good-looking guys playing basketball, fan servicing to the fullest. Compared to other anime I've watched, this one has the least fan service so far. 


The animation was great, it gave the characters a breath of reality. The music, which is always important, was a thumbs-up too, not only because it was nice but also because the right track popped up on the right moment, accompanying and enhancing it. 


The characters were unique in their own ways, each and every one of them having a serious side, sometimes even scary but they never lost a chance to act goofy and silly. 


Lastly, I liked this anime very much and I enjoyed watching it, because it was very interesting and the plot was evolving in a short period of time, however it wasn't overwhelming and disappointing. They took an all-time classic sport like basketball and turned it into a something like an actual fight of skills and spirit. Magnificent job. And the skills each character had was unique, the story never repeating itself like it happens in many anime/manga. For all these reasons mentioned above, the total points this anime gets from me are 9.


Thanks for reading, I hope it was helpful.

Before I get started, let me say that this review is definitely subject to change. Mainly due to that fact that I had to voice my opinion on a really enjoyable anime, I'm writing this before the series is over. I know, writing a review on a series before it's finished reviewing is taboo; however I really feel that this anime needs more recognition. Mainly, I'm here to help those people who can't decide on whether they should watch this anime or not. Trust me, you not going to get  an accurate feel for what you should expect from this anime after just readingthe synopsis. 


Just so you know, I'm not a big basketball fan. If I had to decide, I'd say I don't like basketball. I rarely even watch a game and find little to no enjoyment from playing the sport. However, that didn't stop me from enjoying this anime. For those of you who have watched "Hikaru no Go" or "Prince of Tennis", you already know that you don't necessarily have to understand an anime to enjoy it. This is even more true in sports anime; in fact, it might even be more enjoyable because you can learn a little while having fun.


 To say the least, your going to have a lot of fun watching this anime. Heck, I might have had the most fun watching this anime out of all the series I  have watched, mainly because I thought it was the perfect length for a sports anime. A lot of times you'll notice that sports anime are very long; which a lot of the time makes them very tedious. For me, a prime example would have to be Prince of Tennis. To cut a long story short, it's too long. Spanning 178 episodes, you can already see what I mean. Sure, being over 100 episodes long has worked well for several popular series, and in fact, most of them are still running. Naruto, One Piece, Bleach, and Inuyasha are several of the mainstream anime that span over 100 episodes, and most of them are still immensely popular. So why doesn't it work for series like Prince of Tennis? Because they're sports anime. And one thing you'll notice after watching sports anime is repetition, and lots of it. I mean, how could there not be? There are only 2 ways a sports anime will end, in a win or a loss. I've yet to see a tie, and hell, I've never even seen a loss. Sure, you can change the way they accomplish their goal, but the end result is the same. Even if you change the methods, you're still limited in a sports anime. There are only so many different ways to change the methods. More true than in almost any other sport, basketball is honestly not that flashy. To get around a defender, it usually doesn't require immense ball handling skills, but usually comes down to speed in the end. Which is where I get into my next point.


I've seen a lot of reviews done by (I assume) basketball players ranting on and on about how "unrealistic" this show is. And yes, I do agree with them, a lot of this stuff is unrealistic. But no, I do not agree with them on their opinion that this downgrades the quality of this show; mainly because of how awesome some of the stuff they did was. Without this aspect of sports anime, no one would watch them. Every sports anime is over exaggerated. Do you want to watch someone practice something to only watch them miss over and over again? No. That's why it's over exaggerated. Sure, no one can make every basket they shoot. No one. Sure, the idea of running by moving your arms and legs at the same time in sync is completely ridiculous, but that's okay. You want to know why? Because it's fun. Because it's interesting. And because it makes for one hell of an enjoyable anime.


 Let me just say that the art in this show is really good, if not amazing. You're really going to get sucked in by the awesome effects done to the dunking and passing in this anime. Even the characters always looked crisp and ready to go, which is what usually lacks in sports anime. Mainly while trying to emphasis the background elements that help emphasis the importance of a dunk or 3 pointer, the writers forget that they also have a character there. This usually leaves the characters looking a little... well, dumb. Sure, some of it is a little unrealistic, but who can't deal with a little exaggeration?


I kind of brushed up on it earlier, but you're going to have a lot of fun watching this anime. Why? Let me tell you. First, the synopsis is complete rubbish. Possibly one of the worst I've ever read. Let me clear a few things up for you before we start. Kagami is the main character and has just returned from America and is disappointed at the difference in the skill level between America and Japan. He decides to join his schools basketball team and eventually hears about "the generation of miracles." He becomes excited when he learns that one of his teammates, Kuroko, was a starter for the same team as the Generation of Miracles. He finally gets the chance to play him, but figure out that he actually sucks! Very disappointed, he continues to go to practice. Finally they play a little practice game between the upperclassmen and he figures out that Kuroko is a MASTER at passing. He realizes that they can go far together and realizes at the same time that the Generation of Miracles is, in fact, strong. Loving nothing more than a challenge, Kagami and Kuroko lead their team to the top.


Fun. That's all this anime is, is fun. If you're in an "anime slump", as I call them, and can't seem to find an anime you can finish without getting bored, then this anime is definitely for you. Having been in a slump until just the other day, I can tell you for certain that this is the perfect remedy for a slump. Even if you're not in a slump and are just looking for a fun anime that is somewhat mainstream but still a overall great show, look no further, because your knight in shining armor is here. You may have noticed that my overall is only a mere 8, but that's only because I haven't seen the end yet. As I said before, this review is subject to change. Heck, if this show pulls a gold bar out of its ass, it might even get a 10. Sure, that's not perfect on any scale but that would mean that this is a damn good anime. Not enough can I emphasize the fact that you should not drop this anime simply because it focuses on basketball. I've been guilty of this mistake and I can tell you now that I fully regret my actions. Even if you absolutely hate basketball, don't put this show off without giving it a try. If you do, you'll simply be wasting a chance at watching 25 episodes of pure enjoyment.

Kuroko no Basket is a tough one for me. 
It's the first sports anime i have ever watched. I had always avoided sport anime because I felt they were too unrealistic. 
I'd heard a lot about it and finally decided to try something new. After finishing the first season I felt that it was ok but not the amazing show many people made it out to be. 
Story: the story overall I gave a 5. It's pretty much about some guy named Taiga Kagami trying to beat "the generation of miracles". In this aspect it played out like an unoriginal shonen anime. This was totallyfine as i wan't necessarily expecting the most well written story coming into it. 


Art: The art was really good. I gave it an 8. The animation for various players as they moved around the court was pretty good and added a lot of excitement to the action. 


Sound: I gave it a 7. Not much to say. I found the music enjoyable. 


Characters: This was the shows weakest point. Giving it a 3 was probably a bit nice. It would have gotten worse if it weren't for the personality of Kuroko. The characters are all so bland. Theres little to no back story given beyond "this person used to play with the generation of miracles" or "this person grew up in America". Kagami was your typical headstrong main character who wants to be the best. The worst part about the characters overall was their lack of basketball skills in general. THE MAIN CHARACTER SUCKS AT BASKETBALL! And no it's not like one of those "oh i'll improve and become the best"  Kuroko just sucks...but that's the point. It was so stupid. Why make him the main character if he's going to do nothing but pass. He literally doesn't even dribble the ball. Not once. He just does tap passes. It's painful to watch. 


Enjoyment: 6. It's your typical shonen anime with a basketball twist. If you like shonen you'll like it. If not stay away. Nothing else to say. 


Overall: it was fair. Not good but not bad. Thankfully it wasnt so mediocre it didnt stand out at all. It's watchable. Definitely way over-hyped though.  If you like basketball, shonen anime, and have some time to kill this is your show. Turn it on while doing homework or surfing the internet. It's got 51 total episodes to give you plenty of background noise while working on other things.

Combining elements of Shonen with sports and a stellar cast of characters makes this show amazing. The games themselves are as action packed as 'fight scenes' in other shonen. However the part I loved the most was all the different types of characters. Being part of a team means having to play with many different types of people and this show exposes many different archetypes to the viewers. The most obvious one being the 2 main characters (Kuroko and Kagami being total opposites). If you ever played basketball, that should just one more reason to watch this great anime.

A friendship driven sport series executed superbly, and a great setting to match. The supernatural element makes Kuroko no Basket exciting, intense, and loads of fun. What sets this series apart from the other basketball series is the focus on five extraordinary individuals in their respective teams.
Sport genres tend to have very strong characters developments. The wide range of personalities in this series is both inspiring and entertaining. Character developments are good, underdogs working hard and doing their best to achieve a dream hits everyone’s soft spot.
Kagami is your “everything is possible” hero. He carries the series and the viewers’ hopes. The partnership of Kagamiand Kuroko grows throughout, but with obstacles in between; you will see happy times as well as sad times. Personality-wise, Kuroko doesn’t shine. Yet, when he is on screen, the viewers are made to expect something unusual to happen in a comical manner, or if on the basketball court, some sort of impressive display. Kagami and Kuroko bring out the best of each other both on and off the basketball court; if they were lone characters in separate series, both would have been incomplete. The biggest character developments lie in the “miracle generation” members. We see different sides to their personalities. Their skills develop and their behaviours change; viewers will love them, hate them, and possibly love them again. The support players in the top teams are great supports. They don’t steal the show, but are entertaining enough on their own; everyone has their own goals and pride. Character interactions are realistically captured, often humorous. Every player from the “Miracle Generation” has an exclusive past, and a strong will. They all want to be the best, work hard to achieve what they think they rightfully deserve. It is a battle of kings. There are good uses of flashbacks revealing some past of “The Miracle Generation”, to thrill the viewers.


Exaggerated facial expressions and narrow eyes make many characters look very similar but in different coloured wigs. Some of Kagami’s behaviours remind me much of Sakuragi from Slam Dunk. Basketball movements are fluid. Like all other basketball series, the camera angles show us different perspectives, but also like the others, lots of screen time has characters standing still, listening to their thoughts/dialogues, and camera focusing on the bench, away from the actual game. Also, slow motions galore. Recycled basketball moves and situations were never nice to look at, and some humour was a bit dry. The art might feel slightly outdated on first sight, but it works and does grow on you.


Sound effects are great. The basketball nettings, dribbles, and feet frictions against the polished floors are well done. Background soundtracks are varied, lots of techno during games to get viewers high. Seiyuu have no problem to convey different moods of the characters in the appropriate situations.


The main strengths of this show are its action scenes on the court, the suspense and thrill of each basket, and the risk of losing. But the other main themes certainly don’t lag behind, that is the team bonding, friendship, and trust. The players from the “Generation of Miracles” are ridiculously strong, they can do inhuman actions on a basketball court, making each and every one of them feared and sought after by every college team in the country. Not all the players of “Generation of Miracles” were shown at the same time. Each character was fed to the viewer gradually, each individual is a new obstacle to conquer, and knowing there are stronger opponents after each wall helps build up the excitement and wonderment.


The action will light a fire in your heart; it doesn’t wait for you, they are blink and miss. This is the pace you can expect from the series. Some sequences will make you want to rewind and watch again, not necessarily because you missed them the first time, but because they were awesome and needs to be re-watched to believe.


As a feel good sport series, some results might be predictable. But if who wins is perceivable, might as well make the way it approaches that prominent final score as extravagant as possible.


Watch this if you like Slam Dunk.

Okay for starters Kuroko no Basuke is a basketball anime your probably thinking, oh it's like Slam Dunk welll.. not exactly. I'd say Kuroko no Basuke has more of a supernatural aspect of basketball, where as Slam Dunk's there were alot of episodes focusing on fundamentals. This is isn't a bad thing actually it's what make this anime stand out.
Story~9
The anime isn't finished so I can't say how it's going to sway my opinion on how good the story is, but for now from what I've watched it's been great. I like the fact that the story has a fast pace is never bores youas the story progresses you'll always be on your feet wondering what will happen next. 


Art~ 8 

The characters are made pretty well actually. Very lively looking settings and characters nothing is ever dull.


Sound~7

Well not the best or the worst, but hey we came for the story right I mean I've watched alot of animes where it had a great sound track, but the story lacked like Guilty Crown I find that in the end the story will sway your overall score.


Characters~9

This is another aspect where Kuroko no Basuke excels. I like how all characters have a certain ability where the are good at. I expected there to be a team where everyone is great at all aspects, but the charcters in this anime are balanced. Kuroko is a passer/pg and Kagami is an inside man plays the post game. Sure there abilities aren't realistic, but it sure is fun to watch them pass the ball like it's a beam of energy and dunk from the free throw line. Besides thier skills the characters also have thier certain personalities, Kuroko is a passive/agressive person mostly all nice until something that makes him snap makes him mad. Kagami is more of an aggressive type of person who doesn't like to loose who's spirit can never be crushed.


Enjoyment~10

Honestly I love this anime it's so awesome well, I play basketball a lot so that's the reason, even so I'd recommend this to anyone like I said earlier it's not the typical sports anime it's more supernatural than anything, well regardless if you're a sports fan or a person who likes action you'll fall in love with this anime.

Among all the middle schools and high schools there are in Japan, there is one said to have an unbelievably strong Basketball team unlike any other before them, Teiko middle school's "Generation of Miracles", the next all stars of the Basketball sport, each one gifted in a different area of the sport, although there has said to have only been five members, there was also a rumored "phantom sixth"...
Kuroko's Basketball is an ingenious series that divulges into the sport of Basketball itself, explaining its inner workings and how the characters of the series take the sport to almost superhuman degrees, one could say akin tohow battle themed series develop over the courses of their respective sagas...


The main themes of Kuroko's Basketball are teamwork, a person's love for a sport they are good at and the drive to surpass those with great talent and skill, Kuroko's Basketball focuses on a young man named Tetsuya Kuroko who is in actuality the rumored phantom sixth of Teiko middle school's legendary Basketball team, the Generation of Miracles.


Upon graduating from middle school, each of the six members belonging to the miracles went to a different high school each, in order to be able to meet one another, as rivals on the court with Kuroko being no exception.


It is when Kuroko applies for the Seirin high school's Basketball team that his story truly begins, as he learns to befriend a certain teammate of his named Taiga Kagami and vice versa.


Whereas Kuroko is bland and doesn't stand out, Kagami is hyperactive and takes center stage on Seirin's team, as its new ace but its only through his interactions with Kuroko that both Kagami and Kuroko together learn to work, as a team alongside their other new teammates, as they take on many challengers wanting to prove both their skill and worth on the court.


Learning and growing through each match they face, its not too long before Serin's Basketball team comes to odds and heads to heads with the teams that the other Generation of Miracles members decided to join, through successes and errors, Seirin now takes on the miracles themselves in order to prove they themselves the best, however, its not so easy, as simply just stating it, in order to beat their rivals, they are going to have to take their current levels in Basketball to extremes, especially against the opponents they are facing:


Ryota Kise of Kaijo, Shintaro Midorima of Shutoku, Daiki Aomine of Too, Atsushi Murasakibara of Yosen and finally last but especially not least, Seijuro Akashi of Rakuzan.


These 5 are considered the Generation of Miracles, the best of the best...of the best and Kagami has now made it his mission to defeat all 5 of them, wanting to gain worthy challenges from worthy adversaries...


As for Kuroko while he too wishes to defeat the miracles, it appears that there is something more then meets the eye...either way, Kuroko, Kagami and the rest of Seirin's Basketball team are determined to reach the top and will defeat all opposition along the way, that is the will behind their strength that is the key to victory.


Kuroko's Basketball teaches one about their love for sport, the reasons why they started playing it and why they continue doing so, it also teaches one about how a person can over time because of one reason or another lose that love that got them into their favorite sport and then start seeing said sport, as more of a chore or obligation to uphold...


In one sense of the term, Kuroko's Basketball could definitely almost be viewed, as a battle Manga/Anime series using sport, as its central theme and "means of fighting", including how the series has many rivals the protagonists have to go up against before reaching the very end.


Utmost praise goes towards the strong characterization Kuroko's Basketball has, namely towards its central characters-Kuroko, Kagami and the Generation of Miracles, each of them having different ambitions to one another that keeps them going and moving forwards towards what lies ahead for them.


Despite the majority of the series focused on Basketball, there are comedy moments that could make viewers laugh out loud and if it can even be considered romance, there are very small showings of potential shippings between certain characters in the series.


Story, Art, Sound, Character, Enjoyment and Overall deserve high praise, a lot of detail and work went into the characters that make up most of Kuroko's Basketball's success, "a battle Anime outside of a battle Anime", that is probably the best way to describe this series, it never fails in its showings of official Basketball games between rivals to get adrenaline pumping when you pour yourself into the series and feel like your a part of it, rooting for the team you want to win badly, upon watching this series, that's how i know the characters feel in those win or lose moments, trying to get the very last score right at the very end, i can certainly promise you now, Kuroko's Basketball is certainly an entertaining watch and it might just surprise you, its a probability and possibility at best but still, again...it might just surprise you.


Here's hoping this Review was helpful in any way, Kuroko's Basketball is definitely a good way to start an interest in Basketball itself.

I finished this anime in about a day, if that tells you anything. 
I'm going to start off with the negatives first since there are so few. Firstly, the openings and endings weren't as strong as they could've been, in my opinion. The first opening in particular was good, but after that, it was pretty average. The art was also slightly above average, but nothing too special. Although, some of the shots can look pretty awesome. Other than that, I can't really say much that can be improved with this anime. It isn't so brilliant that I'll be thinking about it when I go tosleep (as I have done with anime like Haikyuu!! and Free!), but I also can't rate it anything under a 10.


The good parts of this anime can be found all over. First of all, the storytelling is fairly solid. Not a lot of holes can be found in a given character's motive or drive. The characters themselves are very well written and voiced, making it difficult to not love them. Even if you don't fall head over heels for them somehow or if they're a character that you're meant to hate, you'll still enjoy watching them because they are so dynamic. I think more than anything else, the characters are what really excel in this anime. The make it shine.


I mentioned a few anime earlier in this review, and if you're interested in those anime, you'll probably like this one. It may not have as much of an impact as those others, but I imagine you'll have a hard time giving it an average ranking, too.

Story: (2/10) (down below)
Art: (5/10) its decent, nothing special
Sound: (7/10) great/decent OPs, nothing you'll love, nothing you will hate too much
Characters: (3/10) only likable charter is a dog, he doesn't even show up for a while and isn't drawn too well but I'm obligated to mention the cute dog (more below)
Enjoyment: (3/10) games get repetitive and even before that you can tell they are cliches (more down below)

So let me just tell you if you are okay with ultra-super-over-the-top powers with little explanation or reason to them, this is your show. All the characters are cliches and eventhe ones who aren't, make themselves into bs cliches. My favorite character is a dog that occasionally appears and it is cute. the dog is the reason I am rating the characters as a (3/10) instead of a 1 or 2. Hi All.
Let me start with telling about myself, I am 23 year old with no interest in basketball at all. I started watching the Kuroko in my 2nd year of college, Yes I am from India and I did Engineering. I watched all the 50 episodes in the week that time. So yes, this is a great anime to watch.
I don't watch much anime (only watched DEATH NOTE, NARUTO), I don't have any idea why Kuruko is not so popular as other anime. But I believe once you start watching it, it be gone more interesting and interesting. 
Main character here is Kuroko, with verylow physical strength and body. But only reason he plays basket is because of his love for basketball. That's the whole point of this series, to tell people do what you want and do a lot and lots of practice to achieve it. I believe in raw talent but if you work hard you can surpass the raw talent.


Its not center about single characters, there are more strong character in the anime, kuroko is all about team work and friendship. 


point is: "We support each other thats why we are a team".

I’m not a fan of most sports, nor do I partake in anything of that nature. I’m like the main character from Hyouka, I prefer to conserve energy rather than spend it unnecessarily. So for someone like me to like a sports show it has to be special in some way. If I was to add one specific series to the title of Kuroko no Basket to emphasize how different it is from actual basketball I would call it Dragonball Z no Basket.
Story
It’s what you come to expect of a sports anime, there is no overlying plot other than winning. The protagonists want to winand the antagonists are an obstacle obstructing this goal. It’s not something so original like the characters playing basketball and whichever team loses, forfeits their lives. So the only real thing that drags Kuroko no Basket down from being a topnotch anime is the overlying plot just because of how generic it is. They explain all basketball terms in a way that it sounds a bit ridiculous at times, it feels like I’m watching someone explain a magical power in some action/adventure anime but it’s a sport. 


Sound


All four the openings for both seasons are great, I listened to them every time. The first ending was very memorable for me as I can recall it right now and I watched the series four months ago, the other endings were somewhat good but I usually skipped them to start the next episode because I’m a binge watcher. All voices fit the characters well and no one has a voice that makes me cringe, so that’s a plus.


Art


Main Antagonists and Protagonists have very distinct character designs in the way that their hair color seems to be modeled after the power rangers. Everyone else for the most part has the hair color you would picture an average Japanese high school student to have, and then you’ve got the pink and green hair? Character designs are nice to look at and the animation is done very well, though the second season does bring out some of the greatest animation I’ve ever seen.


Characters


The protagonist who the show is named (Kuroko) after is quite unique for a sports anime, because he actually sucks at sports. It’s nice to see someone go outside the box for once and make a protagonist who doesn’t excel at the particular focus of the show. The other protagonist Kagami is your typical hotshot sports player, nothing special he does develop throughout the show into more of a team player but we all see that coming. But this show gives the majority of their side characters plenty of screen time and the antagonists do get a decent amount of development and don’t stay one dimensional sports super stars.


Enjoyment


This show is freaking hilarious, I never thought a sports anime could manage to be this funny. The jokes are so well done I wonder if the script writer is a comedian. The basketball games which are the majority of the anime, are very entertaining and since they are the majority of the anime I wasn’t ever bored. You don’t need to know anything about basketball because this anime will explain all the concepts to make it sound animey.


Overall


It’s good, not the best but in my opinion a very solid series. I’m not a fan of sports anime so I just can’t rate this very high, but that’s just me and my non-sporty self.

Kuroko's basketball is an overall 10 for me. It's a must watch anime. The story is great as well as the OST's and the Characters are, well, HOT and great. the story might be a bit unrealistic (well, it is shounen) but yes, it is a good anime. MUST WATCH :)

"What makes an anime great and fun to watch is its uniqueness and unexpectedness and this goes to show that Japan can or cannot fail to amuse me."
                   Before I gather my conclusions and opinions about this show, I will give you my first impressions on Kuroko no Basket. This show aired in our country and I wasn't interested because I thought it was some dumb copy-cat show and it just made a Slam-Dunk imitation. My friends wanted me to watch it because it is informative and a good show. I, on the other hand, couldn't bring myself to watch this piece of crap and I don't want to witness this unworthy impersonating anime.                    For starters, an anime could be realistic and unrealistic but this one has both. People could say that a show is a show unless its hypothetical  and people would be mad about this anime because it is not like the basketball matches we see on NBA and other basketball programs, It has some sort of twists and turns. I can't imagine myself trying to watch this, at first .. okay a blue-haired guy and a tall, masculine red haired guy joining forces to be the best in Japan.. that sound simple but their journey on how to get there is simply exquisite and reasonably awesome.                         The drawing is pretty good. It is in HD, it is modern and I think I saw this art somewhere but this one is outstanding. The hair colors are different which is easier to see which character is playing, talking or being pointed at. the artist made a good job in creating distinct hair styles and colors.

There were suspense soundtracks which nailed every scene. The anime is pretty lively so expect that the music may give you that adrenaline rush kind of feeling.
