                         I had this good feeling when watching this show, feeling of enjoyment, excitement, greatness, and my expressions were indescribable. ecchi moments were actually uncomfortable but you know.. it's Japan they like those stuff so I think I can handle those.... Ecchi moments. Every game has many surprises and I believe that people can have good feedback about this show.


                        Overall this anime is good. You can watch it during your past time and continue to live that experience. Watching this anime not only gave me entertainment but it linked me to have trust, friendship and hope. Sometimes we only watch anime in order to have something to watch or to enjoy but little did we know there are lessons behind these shows. I know I'm being corny but believe me.. this show is that good.

The first 10 episodes were very entertaining, introducing the audience to a unique world of intense basketball games and players with supernatural abilities. However the show stopped being entertaining when the matches continuously introduced new characters with ridiculous super powers and deux es machina plot twists. I especially found it ridiculous how our main protagonist, who is a really weak and pathetic basketball player, and his teammates are able to defeat all of their formidable opponents who are supposed to be undefeatable, because our main players suddenly develop unforseen abilities in the middle of the game. 
**SPOILER ALERT**I mean seriously all the basketball matches inthe latter episodes can be summarized by the following plot : 1) Our main protagonist, Kuroku, and his team are matched against extremely strong opponents. 2) Kuroku and his team are crushed in the first 2 quarters of the game. 3) By the 3rd or 4th quarter one or more players on Kuroku's team are able to surpass their limits and become super strong so that 4) Kuroku and his team win the match by 1 or more points.

I'm not a big fan of sport animes but one thing is sure I do like very much basketball. The reason i started to watch Kuroko No Basket was because my friends were arguing many times about this anime and how comic it is. Sure there are things the are impossible to do in basket like send the presence to somewhere else or even make unseeing blocks/cuts. But the physics of the anime are very simliar to real life. Like some people say that is impossible to make those Midorima throws or even those Kuroko full court passes. One thing is sure...You couldnt be morewrong. It is possible to make those throws and passes, not like them for sure it acquires more tecnique and strength. I played nacional basketball on my country and my old teammate who were a base always could make me a full court pass when i was alone counter attacking. Another teammate i had could score half court many times. Just for the record we only lose one game with that strategy, it was very efficient. But hey!! Its an anime ;D! Its supposed to show us things we liked to do in real life if it was possible...And its because that surprises and uncapable things that grabs us on the sit to watch them. Criticize its easy...When you are capable of doing better you can say whatever you want ;). If you dont like just drop it and forget it. People who like an anime will never like your bad criticism so just shut your mouth xD. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND KUROKO NO BASKET!

While watching this, the only thing I can think of is how I really want to watch Slam Dunk instead. To me this anime doesn't even come close.
 I really hate the unrealistic part of it but what I hate most is that even when it's unrealistic their "special moves" are really lacking. If you think about it, most of the moves are about the disappearance of the ball or of a person in front of the person playing against them, but everyone watching also see them disappearing from the court! Also, a lot of times you see someone thinking of something and people wouldalways answer as if they heard it. 


I've seen a lot of sports anime that I liked which were also unrealistic but this one is just too lacking. The humor wasn't that good either.


The one thing I really liked was that girls in this anime are strong for once. The Japanese really love the weak female character that is just too annoying, but it was a surprise to see that all of the female characters were strong in their own way.


The initial idea of the MC being great at passing is new and unique. It just wasn't executed well.

Kuroko no Basket, a shounen sports anime. 
It's a very hyped up anime and I can see why is that so. Many recommendation from friends, many facebook pages of this anime and it's ranking here compelled me to check it out. I had high expectations of this sports anime while watching it and I must say, I was not disappointed. It gives the exact feeling and atmosphere a sports anime should have.
The fast paced action and drive pumps you up while watching this anime. Even though it's all about sports, that's not what happens all the time. Side arcs are really fun to watch andthe comedy is pretty nice. I'm glad I started this anime and plan to watch it till the end. So, let's get down with the review;


Story 9/10:

The Generation of Miracles, a group of 6 legendary middle school students who excel at basketball and each one of them graduates from middle school and goes to play for his own high school. 

Kagami Taiga, a high school student from America is a first year student at Seiren High and joins the basketball club alongwith Kuroko Tetsuya. Practice, games, wins and losses are all part of the story. Kagami is determined to beat every one of the Generation of Miracles and therefore, teams up with Kuroko and the Seiren High Basketball club to win the Inter-High Championship.

This season concentrates on 4 of the GoM and the Inter High Title. It is as you would expect from a shounen anime; facing strong opponents, getting backed into a corner and then suddenly coming out of top. Though, it is quite as expected, the games take really quick turns and one can't help but stay excited during the games.


Characters 8/10:

The characters, especially the players each have their own unique ability. The GoM are especially well made. Each having his own personality and ability. Can't really say I hate any of them since all of them are awesome in their own aspects. And some girls in the series freshen things up otherwise it would've been too plain.


Art 8/10:

The art is really good for this anime, no doubt. The reason I gave it a 7 because of the shadow lines under the chins and faces. When you look at them closely, the characters look pretty strange, like aliens or something. Once seen, it's hard to unsee. I remember looking at the characters strange because of those shadows. But if you overlook that and take it for the effect it is meant to give, it isn't that bad. Apart from that, the art is really good. All characters are pretty well designed and you can't complain that it had bad art.


Sound 7/10:

Nothing special, nothing bad. The opening or ending weren't worth listening to everytime and weren't so bad that you would regret listening to them.


Enjoyment 9/10:

The games got me excited, the comedy made me laugh, the characters were good to see, everything was enjoyable. The games are by far the most enjoyable aspect(duh). The fast paced games get your blood pumping. Quick change of flow and awesome techniques leave you amazed. It was definitely an enjoyable watch and I was able to complete the first season in one day without getting bored.


Overall, this anime is well worth it's reputation and I would recommend it to anyone who wants to watch some fast paced, hyper anime that gets your blood pumping alongwith some laughs.

Okay to start off, my other review on Kuroko no Basket got removed because I was overzealous or some shit.  Truth is I had caps lock on on accident.  But really, Kuroko no basket is an entertaining anime that will always have you wondering what will happen next.  It's not like most sports anime because this one has mother fukking super powers.  This just adds to the excitement like when Kuroko kamme hamme has the ball down the court and it kills someone.  This anime also has great animation overall.  The shading will seem a bit strange when youstart with the thick black lines, but you will get used to it.  This anime isn't going to make you think about philosophies of humanity or something like Parasyte attempts to do.  This anime gets right down to the damn point. Basketball.  Super powers.  Watch it.

Although "basketball sports anime" might not seem like the most interesting show from first hearing about it, this show definitely delivers in terms of cool concepts.  It has many different players with their own interesting pasts and cool styles of play.  The styles, while absolutely are unrealistic, serve to make this show extremely interesting to see what style ultimately prevails over another. 
The beginning of the show definitely made this concept clear, and definitely caught my attention, but the middle of the show started to become a little too formulaic for my liking.  However, after a certain event occurs (no spoilers here)the final part of the season (the last 7 episodes or so) were phenomenal.  I unsure in the middle if i wanted to continue on to the second season and continue on with Seirin High School as they go to the winter tournament, but after that ending I can absolutely say I will be watching it in the future... probably while I'm at school.  Can't wait.\n\n
Sentence:  Also, this show is really funny at times.

You like basketball? You like anime? If you like the following, then damn sure you will like this anime, a lot.
Usually, all sports anime have one thing in common with all of their stories, and that is to be the best in that sport. This anime is one of the many other anime that have done really well sticking to its story. Even if there was a filler, it was because that parts of the story may have been needed to be explained. There isn't a lot of dragging,  but I am annoyed at the fact that one quarter of a match is 1or more episodes. If you watch and play basketball, like I do, then you would be surprised at what the players can do. Some of them can shoot from the backcourt, some having the ability to fly up in the air or maybe copying an opponent's move without practicing it. Yes it sounds crazy, but if you were watching a basketball anime, you'd like to see something unexpected. If you don't like watching superhuman powers, then you might as well just watch an NBA game. Also, if you know the rules of basketball, then you would be angry at screaming at a player that does a travel and it isn't called.


For me, the art style in the anime gets progressively better each season. The animation is quite smooth but it gets progressively smoother and smoother, with more abilities being revealed from each character. The colours of their hair may seem unnatural, but hey, this is anime.


The sound was probably one of the main factors in this anime and the reason why this anime succeeded. The soundtracks that play actually engage your emotions and give you goosebumps. I was shaking because of how epic a match was! I also liked most of the OP and ED. It was really catchy for me.


For me, there weren't any characters that I disliked at all, even if they were an antigonist. Each character was very unique and had their own unique abilities. The GoM were introduced as a scary and overpowered, but once they are defeated, they show their weak or good side, making them likeable. The character development in the anime wasn't too rushed. If they wanted to train their abilities, it isn't just a POOF and here is a godly power where you stop time and block every shot. They work hard and have a hardworking ability. Also, this anime shows that the protagonist always wins in some situations.


I enjoyed this anime a lot. A cousin of mine showed me this anime and since that day, I was really addicted to this anime. I would be shaking if there was an epic scene in anime. This anime also made me go back to playing basketball, so thanks Kuroko.


Overall, a 9/10. There are a lot of cliff hangers in the anime, but that's more of a reason to continue watching. Would I re-watch this? Yes, I would love to.

Kuroko no basket is a sport anime. It may seem boring to watch an anime about a sport if you do not like sports, but at the same time it's not only about the sport itself. It has a great focus on the bonding between the players of each team and it also teaches a lesson, to never give up.
The above phrase describes the whole anime pretty well. The characters want something, they have a gold which they want to complete together and, truth be told, that's the only way to do it. There is trust amongst them and they each believe in each otheras well. 


Even when everything seem lost, even when they do lose, they always manages to move forward. They cry, and they get disappointed but, they also have been through a lot, and not only at the current time. They have a history, and they carry a lot. All those things are what makes them take another step forward. 


Now, for the sport funs, Kuroko no basket may seem more fictional than realistic but, it's not such a bad thing. Because it shows all the great moments of basket in every game, it's more interesting and you get hooked easier. It's intense, the andrenaline is seriously high -and I am not talking about the players'- and there is always the desire for more. 


While watching season 1, it's expected to gradually consider the possibility that it cannot go further, that it cannot be better. Well, IT CAN. It always manages to become more awesome, it always manages to go one level up. You see something and you say that's it, that move can't become better, that one player doesn't have a move to defeat the other's player team, this whole thing is over. But, there is always more. Even if one team cannot win, the players always improve. 


And yes, the main team is one, Seirin, but it also shows the other teams. It shows their hopes, their ways, their practices... You end up not being able to take one side but with contradicting feelings.


This anime seriously worths the time spending to watch it, even reading the manga. All three seasons are especialy good. They are epic -and I am not exagerrating-.

Kuroko no Basket.. just hearing the title will pique your interest right?
Prince of Tennis, Hajime no Ippo, Eyeshield 21, Slam Dunk.. most of these titles is one of your faves right? Then be sure to add this anime into your list of faves.
I've read the manga and I can say that the anime is doing good. Or more over I'm starting to love it more than the manga.
Story: 9/10
Well the anime is still sticking with the manga so I'm really happy with that. 
The first episode will immediately grab your heart away. It's unique on its own. Will remind you of Slam Dunk because ofthe setting and comedy. But nope. Even though they have the same element which is Basketball, they still have different storyline.  And I think the way they play the game is much realistic compared to Slam Dunk. No slow motion movements or reminiscing about the past when they're about to shoot the ball or something.


Animation: 10/10


I can't believe that the animation of this anime is uber awesome. Yes! The character (Especially Kuroko and Kise) looks totally awesome and cool! The art of the manga is really nice already.. but the animation of this anime is just really good. Seriously.


Sound: 10/10


Awesome opening and ending songs. Even the background musics are really good. You can really feel the "heat" of the game.


Characters: 10/10


I love all the characters. The protagonist, Kuroko, is not your typical "hero" in the anime. Even Kagami. These two are really made for each other. Putting aside my fangirlness, I didn't mean it in a yaoi way. What I mean is, their tandem is really good.


Each character has a "personality".


Enjoyment: 10/10


I totally enjoy it even though I've only watched 4 episodes so far. Well I've read the manga, but still watching it is much more awesome. Since I totally enjoy watching sports anime than reading it.


Overall: 9/10


This anime is really great. The comedy, no sappy romance, thrilling sensation.. really worth watching it~

Kuroko no Basket is my very first Sport anime. I didn't expect sport to be that exciting though. Or this anime just makes Basketball feel really interesting. Now I love basketball, daisuki! I wonder would a real life basketball fan come to love this or not? 
Story: 10
Everything wasn't just about basketball that made me excited, there's also hilarious comedy which relaxed me during the hard and suspense matches. And during those matches I learned a lot from the characters here.
Story is really thrilling, unpredictable. It's not just about basketball, I mean it's more than basketball, the matches were not boring at all, since thereare many skillful players than just Kuroko X Kagami.\n
My phrases suck >.< but when you watch it you'll definitely understand what I said...\n
Art: 8\n
At first I really dislike how they draw the characters' neck and some, pretty annoying with those //// or \\ of the art style.\n
But now I don't mind that anymore, might have got used to it though :)\n
Sound: 7\n
It was fair to be exact, if we don't count the first opening song.\n
Character: 10\n
Kagami is kind of aggressive, Kuroko is kind of occult, but 2 of them have their own attractions, i.e. no complains about them. The generation of miracles are really special as expected (although 2 of them were shown in the very late episode 25)\n
The others of Seirin made my day, they have such sense of humor, and they are kind of interesting for supporting roles.\n
Enjoyment: 10\n
It never stressed me. Some serious/ story scenes are really enjoyable.\n
Overall: 9\n
Must watch the next seasons to decide the whole thing.\n
My notes of keen-on-rewatch episodes (these are just not my most favorite ones though):\n
- ep 17: Nice match: Kagami vs Aonomi. Turns out it's a big twist in ep 18\n
- ep 21 & 22: a little rest (no match, more comedy-like) and character developments, kind of.

"Its an anime about kids playing basketball, its boring" 
                                               YOU HAVE NO IDEA!
I don't know HOW they did it, but they made a simple sport of basketball more intense than most anime FIGHTS I have everseen. Basketball being more intense than combat, how is it even possible? Well this anime did it. Although there is no combat in this anime, this has a lot of action!


Story - Tall red head Japanese guy comes back from America, joins Japanese school and joins their basketball team. What people didn't know was his rising potential. His goals are to defeat the 5 greatest basketball players in Japanese high school basketball known as the "Generation of Miracles" Long story short, he teams up with their invisible 6th member to take them down as an amazing team duo. 

Great story, very unique, very well explained.


Art - Nice art, looks good, very modern. They made the animation look great during plays, sweat, the jumps, the throws, the passes. 


Sound - Realistic basket ball noises with a bit of anime extra sound effects.


Characters - We got a bunch of characters with their own unique abilities, generation of miracles all have their own hair color which is a nice look.


Enjoyment - Definitely enjoyable, the more the story progresses the more intense it gets. This anime is doing it right. Outside of a person's dislike for basketball, I see no reason anyone would dislike this anime.


Overall - 9/10

"Why should I watch this if I'm not even into basketball?" is what I thought when people recommended this anime to me.
The only anime about sports that I had ever seen sucked (in my opinion of course) and I wasn't sure if this was something for me. But I gave it a try and was everything but disappointed.
Plot & Episodes
Let's get started with how the animeis built. The story revolves around the basketballteam from Seirin High School. Freshmen Kagami and Kuroko both decided to join the team and display their unique basketball skills. As a team, they try to make it to the Inter-High competition,which is a championship with the country's best teams. Not a very uncommon plot seeing that this is a sports anime. What makes the story worth it is the characters and the development of these characters.\n
Most of the episodes are built around a basketball game, be it 'official' ones or practice games. Throughout these episodes, you get to know (a few of) the members of 'The Generation of Miracles': kids that used to play for the superior Teiko Middle School team, but went their separate ways after Middel School (Kuroko was one of them; the phantom sixth member).\n\n
Characters & Development\n
As I said, one thing that makes the anime worth it are the characters. They might seem typically shonen at first: bright hair colors, stereotype personalities and done-before characteristics. I, however, have the feeling that the characters are this, and much more. For example, Kagami might have that stereotypical "never quit, I will win"-agressive-style attitude that we've all seen before, and Midorima is the cool-glasses-guy who acts stuck up and knows best, but the way they behave and their actions beg to difference. The characters manage to capture my attention because they are unpredictable in their stereotype (if such a thing even makes sense... just watch the anime and you'll know what I mean). \n\n
Visual & Sound\n
These were, so to say, OK. Not outstanding, but not distracting either. I do think they could have done more with the visuals. Especially considering the moves the characters make, I think they could have made it far more spectacular visually. The camera-perspective the anime takes up could also be improved. You often get the same perspective, while they could have made it far more interesting if they swtiched up perspectives and introduced new ones more.\n\n
Theme\n
This is a thing where the anime in my opinion excells. The theme seems to be basketball or sports, but I specifically think it's team sports. \n
Let me start with saying that, even if you don't know the rules and regulations of basketball: no problem. The anime doesn't explicitly explain any, but you will understand more of it along the way.\n
This brings me to the struggles, feelings, thoughts, worries and problems the characters encounter, although a lot of the moves and actions made during games are very unrealistic for a couple of high school kids, are so so recognizable. I myself don't play basketball, but I'm a vivid field hockey player. Take for exemple [this might be a spoiler] Kuroko who tells Kagami that he used to hate basketball back at Teiko. How much it hurts to hate something you love and what it's like when your opponents lose the will to play, wich is the case with Aomine. When lose the will to do something you like most. These aren't superficial worries, but a legit form of sports psychology. I myself had the exact same experience: I transfered to a team where I started to hate hockey. I didn't want to train or play and it made me afraid to go to the training. The fear and/or hate might be irrational at some point, but it's there: One thing this anime does especially well is tackle actual problems everybody can encounter while playing a team sport (or maybe even in individual sports, but I wouldn't know since I don't play that ^^"). This anime has actually helped me look at my own life differently. I wouldn't go as far as say it's life changing or anything, but I'm sure I'll start tomorrow's game with another mindset and with 'The Basketball which Kuroko Plays' in the back of my head.

My score may seem biased, but I am a huge Basketball fan, I play all the time (I'm awesome at it) and watch the NBA regularly, but I really enjoyed it. It may have some BS in it, but I think that this "BS" gives it a new feel to the game. The story is awesome, the art is awesome and the sound is awesome. But what I like most of this is the characters, everything is not centered around the main characters but shows a lot of the minor characters, which I think makes it really cool. Overall it is awesome, I really recommendthis to anyone who loves Basketball, even if you don't like Basketball, I think you should give it a try.\n\n
You won't be disappointed

Let's start with a sentence that will make you wonder why I even started watching this serie; 
I hate basketball. Still, I'm giving this serie high numbers, even outstanding ones. Well that is easily explained. Kuroko no Basket is pretty much like Prince of Tennis, if you think about it. It's about a sport, but still.. it kind of is not. The characters tend to have superhuman reflexes, flexibility, speed, "ultimate moves" excetera. But that, my friends, is why it makes a good anime serie. 
The way how this series art is made, is just outrageously beautiful. When shit goes down, you really feel itgoin' down. Everything is in ultimate combination with each other - Art, sound, characters. Which ofcourse gives it a high enjoyment rate. 


Kuroko no Basket is much more high-paced and unrealistic than real basketball, which makes it actually fun. A guy can throw a ball in from the other side of the court, other one can dunk from half a court excetera. And they execute it in such a marvelous, goosebumps giving way, it is just beautiful. The characters are really well made, and they are all unique in the way they play, the way they feel, and the way they act. Getting to know more characters almost every episode, and none of them are dull or hastily made. 


Many words put into few, if you enjoy fast paced, sports anime with "special moves", this anime is definitely for you. Even if you hate basketball - Like I do. Did. 


On purpose I chose not to disclose anything related to characters, their relations or how they are connected to each other, to prevent spoilers. 


Enjoyment rating is a strong 9.

Who would watch an anime about sports, when you can go outside and play sports?  I hear that lame reasoning all the time and after witnessing my first sports anime, I have to politely disagree with that statement.  Simply put, Kuroko no Basket is the pure embodiment of hype.  The buzzer beater moments are in another world and abilities are so crazily awesome that they come off as likable and awe-inspiring.
Kuroko no Basket gives me such a passion for basketball, that it almost makes me want to play the game IRL.  I know that sounds crazy.  An anime fan wantingto play basketball?  However, all it takes to put down that dream and to shoot it back down into the depths of my teenage mind is to recall how hard I got destroyed in a 1v1 of basketball with my friend.  I mean he just threw the ball between my legs and went behind me.  It felt like a Generation of Miracles player wrecking an average player.  My friend does not even play basketball sigh.


Anyway, Kuroko no Basket's story is pretty good.  It seems what anime would produce out of a sports series.  We have these chosen gods of basketball and yet there's this one underdog among them.  He will be our protagonist.  In season 1, a large portion of the story is this summer tournament.  The team of Seirin featuring our protagonist, Kuroko, and a super tall red-haired center, Kagami, must attempt to surpass regionals and enter the Inter-High, where they will face teams all over Japan.  This sounds like standard affair, yet, the storylines of the characters and their ambitions enrich the storyline.

The story itself is not the best, but the characters definitely push it up there.


The character cast is flourishing with a variety of bizarre characters.  Kuroko is an interesting protagonist that is very likable and charismatic.  His quiet tendencies and surprising shenanigans appearing out of nowhere never seem to get old.  Kagami as another main character proves to be weaker than Kuroko.  A problem with his character is that we never know his backstory or history.  The viewer only knows that he played basketball in America.  What else about him can make him a more compelling character?


The supporting cast is flourishing with likeable characters as well.  The Generation of Miracles players are super badass and you want to see every single one of them completely destroy people.  The team that the main characters are on has some nice personalities too.  The captain is decent.  Overall, solid characters that could use some backstory.  I mean a supporting character (a Generation of Miracles member) has more description and childhood knowledge than our main characters!  What's up with that?!


I'll put Art and Sound together because they are both around the same: very good.  The art is generally solid.  In and out of games characters look good, but not exceptional.  I wouldn't say that they just "get the job done" with animation.  It's definitely a level higher than that because they are no remarkable errors within it.  There is never a moment of inconsistency.  Sound is also great.  Granrodeo makes some amazing OPs and the EDs are better than expected.  The OPs help cement pure hype in the viewers with its electrifying guitar rifts and passionate vocals.  


Enjoyment is where Kuroko no Basket shines.  The heat of the games and the stakes of them increase tenfold every time.  Each match becomes more exciting as both sides break out new aces and new tricks up their sleeves.  The swift passes of Kuroko and the epic skills of Aomine (character later in the second half) make for some exhilarating moments.  I mean if you really get into it, you might have some basketball tendencies.  I joke with my friends when we throw an object and it lands unexpectedly in the right place.  We then say "Anywhere in the court man!" a reference to Kuroko no Basket.


Problems I have with Kuroko no Basket are as follows:

-Weak first half, Kuroko no Basket takes a while to get going to its fullest potential.  There is also not enough exposition for the training for their first tournament.  Without all of the practice montages, the games at the beginning felt less impactful than they could have been.  Once it gets going, the anime improves drastically, but I can't ignore that fault.

-Main characters needing more backstory, I'm really curious on how Kuroko enters the basketball scene or how Kagami is treated in America as a Japanese player.  How did their experiences shape who they are? (lame ass high school topic right there)

-SOMETIMES too much talking in between hype moments, look.  I'm watching anime and I can handle some surrealism.  However, sometimes Kuroko no Basket takes it a bit too far.  I kinda facepalm when a ten second conversation passes over one single jump battle.  I mean just slam it or defend it already!  I like knowing the thoughts of the characters in the heat of the moment, but it can drag on and on, detracting from the hype.

-Weak comedy first half, for some reason, the comedy was pretty mediocre at the beginning.  As the characters grew on me and I knew about them a bit better, the comedy was a lot better and worked on me.

-Sometimes a bit predictable, don't want to spoil what happens, but how games turn out can grow stale and repetitive.


A nitpick that others have, that doesn't apply here:

It's too fake!  The powers are too broken, BOOHOO!  Anime can be a great place for imagination to go wild.  It's great that the creators are letting their brains rack up these crazy ideas to entertain the viewer.  Anime is where anything can be put to life.  Unlike real life videos, they do not have the boundaries created by equipment, physics laws, etc. Let Kuroko no Basket blow you away.  If you accept how crazy it can become, how overpowered some characters appear to be, how over the top, a high school basketball game can be, watch it!  You will definitely be pumping your hands in the air at a three pointer or a crazy play!

Honestly, when I first heard of Kuroko no Basket, I had no intentions of watching it whatsoever since I wasn't a major sports fan. And I'm not saying that I hate sports; I actually like to play basketball, football, & bandminton. But I wasn't a hard-core fan about it and watching an anime show about sports seemed boring to me. But when I watched the first episode, I was hooked! I literally couldn't stopped watching!
Story: 8/10
There was nothing really special or unique about the story line. It was actually pretty decent and very original. It's basically about a high school basketball team trying to beatthe 'Generation of Miracles', which are pro high school basketball players that each has it's own ability. There are no twists or turns in the plot which will surprise you or keep you guessing what will happen next, but it is absolutely very entertaining. It has good comedy and the pace is not too slow nor is it too fast. The only thing that will bother the heck out of you though will be the introduction that plays every time in the beginning of the episode and it won't stop until like half-way through the series. I actually memorized the lines of it to be honest. That's how repetitive it was.\n
Art: 7/10\n
The art was alright; it was nothing major or magnificent. The characters aren't drawn skinny-looking though like what you will see in most animes, they were drawn muscular and large, but it's not a bad thing, I quite like it.\n
Sound: 10/10\n
The music was AMAZING! Of course it wasn't the best that I've heard, but the soundtracks that they used were really good. Every opening song and ending song they played were nice and it fit the anime very well.\n
Character: 10/10\n
The characters are the main key point in Kuroko no Basket. They were all just very reasonable and unique. It can be hard to pick a favorite character to be honest since they were pretty much likable. But in my opinion, Kuroko was my favorite character ^~^ hehe. Anyhow, I really like the fact that each individual had their own different ability that they specialize at; that makes the character even more complex. They all had their strengths and weaknesses; and they also had their very own reason why they started to play basketball.\n
Overall:\n
All in all, Kuroko no Basket is a very enjoyable anime that anyone should consider watching whether they like sports or hate it. The stunts that they do in the basketball games may seem impossible to do and it should've never been done in a real-life game, but hey, it's anime and it also puts more intensity and 'action' into the show. Kuroko no Basket is in my top ten now, so give it a shot! :)\n

Impossible - that is the most common word you can hear from the audiences who watched this show, but actually the impossibility add enjoyment to the show. As a basketball player, I can say that the series doesn't actually possess "basketball education" but it makes us think to mimic those moves in the court just for fun. As an Anime lover the story is interesting. Overall, in spite of the impossibility of their moves, we can get fun just by following the story. Who knows, maybe a person can actually mimic it perfectly just by watching the show.

Sports and I are something that does not really belong together, like Code Geass and a second season. I have no real interest in any sport, so usually I stay away from most sports anime. Most of them follow the generic path of a certain team playing a certain sport, the team wining most of their games and losing a couple of them. To all extents and purposes “Kuroko’s Basketball” follows this exact pattern, but had one nice twist to it that made it worth some wild.
“Kuroko’s Basketball” follows personality devoid Kuroko and his rag-tag team of high school misfits as they try and beatother high schools, some of them having players from the “Generation of Miracles,” a former middle school basketball team with exceptional players, but for some reason most say that there were only five members of the “Generation of Miracles,” even though Kuroko was one of the members also apparently. I mean, every time we meet another member of the “Generation of Miracles” they completely acknowledge that Kuroko is an amazing player, so why the misconception?


Well apparently the reason for this misconception is that Kuroko has the presence of a blank sheet of paper. Literally, players on the court will completely forget that Kuroko is even playing because of his lack of presence. Another thing that could make Kuroko forgettable is the fact that he is terrible at basketball. For a title like “Kuroko’s Basketball” one would expect Kuroko to be front in center, making three pointers while jumping 50 feet in the air. But in the first episode the anime explains quite clearly how much Kuroko sucks at the sport. In fact the best player on the team is no good delinquent Taiga Kagami, who sports red hair to show the audience how angry he is all the time because red equals GRRRRR I’M ANGRY! The series then follows Kuroko and Kagami who team up, with Kagami having actual talent with Kuroko being able to pass the ball to him with nobody else noticing. 


The story of “Kuroko’s Basketball” is nothing to gawk at, I mean once you see the team win one game you’ve pretty much seen them win them all. The only interesting point to the show that I found was the fact that the main character is not technically the star of the anime. Kuroko has to help out all the other players on the team, a value that is little explored in a lot of sports anime, and fits well of a game like basketball. It made it interesting at times to see how the team would use Kuroko to effectively beat the other team, imploring a sense of strategy. Only problem is that after the first couple of games the only real thing Kuroko does is pass the ball quickly and soon the effect of “Whoa who saw that guy coming,” gets old soon. Also after Kuroko’s team gets their ass handed to them in episode 18, the series comes to a complete halt with boring training episodes and watching other teams play. It’s an incredibly anti-climactic ending to a series, one that is banking on the fact that there will be a second season. (At the time of this review a second season will be premiering in October.)


The character of Kuroko is about as interesting as the plain piece of paper I mentioned earlier in the review, having no real motivation, personality, interesting backstory. All we know about him is that he played on the “Generation of Miracles,” making for a bland main character.  Kagami is pretty much in the same boat as Kuroko; only his main personality trait is being mad and angry. The two characters have nearly no chemistry, making for an uninteresting paring that should be the heart of the series. Interestingly enough the show tries to explore the relationships of Kuroko and the other members of the “Generation of Miracles.” Most of it boils down to in the end either a player liking Kuroko or hating him because of his school choice. There also seems to be a bigger focus on the “Generation of Miracle,” then there is Kuroko’s team, with the last big game of the series involving two different members of the “Generation of Miracles.” With more of a focus on the “Generation of Miracles” the main team in question becomes less interesting as the series progresses. Oddly also the series only features three of the five members of the “Generation of Miracles,” holding out the last two for the second season. All I’ve got to say about that is they better be gods at basketball considering how one of the members introduced, Daiki Aomine, can literally score upwards of 60 points in one half. 


The animation of “Kuroko’s Basketball” is fluid, with attention to detail during the games themselves. Most games are nicely animated, making every game at least somewhat enjoyable to watch. Character designs for the main characters have different color hair, to represent their personalities and to differ them up from all the other players that look exactly like them. On Kuroko’s team there was several times where I forgot which player was who because nearly all of them looked identical. Not that it terribly matters; the only real people who the show focuses on are Kuroko and Kagami.

The two openings for the show are serviceable, being able to hype one up for the show, while the first ending I thought was great. Seriously, I thought the first ending is one of the best ending songs I’;ve heard in a while being catchy and a nice way to end an episode. Most anime series now a days sick any random song at the end (see Kuroko’s Basketball’s second ending), but the music they picked for the first ending was great in my opinion. Most background music was nice, making the games quite intense at time. All in all nothing that stood out (except of course for that great ending). 


In the end, ones enjoyment of “Kuroko’s Basketball” depends on how much they enjoy most sports anime. Coming from someone who cannot stand sports, I found “Kuroko’s Basketball” enjoyable at times. The nice little twist the premise adds, the animation and the first opening makes “Kuroko’s Basketball” stand out a little bit from other sports anime, but besides for that the show is generic in nearly all other categories. I do plan on watching the second season and am hoping that the show is able to fix the character problems plaguing the story (i.e. focus more on Kuroko’s team, work on better chemistry, give more motivation’s, etc.), for if they can fix that they would have a real winner.


OVERALL: “Kuroko’s Basketball” is taking some steps in the right direction with a focus on the whole team, but sloppy character development hold the series back from being truly fun.

Before deciding to watch Kuroko no Basket, I was very hesitant. I had heard both negative and positive feedback about the series, and since I am a tough critic when it comes to sports anime, I ended up putting it off. However, after giving the first episode a try I was instantly hooked. 
The thing that really strikes me in the anime is the main protagonist. Characters are the usually the most critical part of an anime for me, and I was very surprised. Typically, the main character in a sports/shounen anime is always determined to be the "ace" or the best. However, that isnot the case in Kuroko no Basket. Kuroko, who is a short and weak first year tries out for the Seirin basketball team. As the "phantom man" and sixth member of the five generation of miracles, Kuroko is relatively unknown. Unlike most sports anime, the main protagonist is supporting the deuteragonist, Kagami, in Kagami's to become the best in Japan. 


The anime mainly focuses on the relationship between Kuroko and Kagami and how they develop together (along with the rest of the Seirin team). Throughout the episodes, the development in all characters are very prominent. The interactions with each other, (and other teams) are very enjoyable and engaging. Each character is individualised, and has a unique set of characteristics. The players on Serien all have skills and abilities that help to influence and compliment the skills of other players on the team. By working together, they improve not only their own basketball style, but the others as well. 


Also, unlike anime several other basketball anime, Kuroko no Basket has some unrealistic features, such as skills. (ex. Kuroko's "vanishing drive" or Akashi's "emperor eye") Although, this makes the anime interesting. The games are more intense, and watching the characters develop and gain those skills is very enjoyable. 


For a sports anime, Kuroko no Basket has very good art. The animation is very fluid, however it isn't a masterpiece. Taking the anime's budget into consideration, the animation is terrific. The art adds on to the overall watching experience, and the style is very good. 


Overall, I would say that Kuroko no Basket is a great show. As a basketball player myself, I can see how some people view the show as "unrealistic" however, the skills are based on actual moves used by professional players. (ex Kagami's meteor jam was based on a slam dunk initiated by leaping over the free throw line) I think that most shounen fans would be very pleased by Kuroko no Basket.

Story 9/10:
The plot is very simple: beat the best teams in the country. As a basketball player and fan, I feel like this anime’s plot captures the concept of having fun competing. What I enjoy most about Kuroko No Basuke is that it has what people clicked to see: basketball. It doesn’t pad out its run time by trying to shove exposition in our face, instead we mostly are getting prepped for the next game to be played. Episodes that allow us to cool off from the action in between games are entertaining because the utilize the colorfulness of the cast. Otherwise, action is 70%of this show with a little exposition here and there which suits a high paced sports anime like this very well. It gives us what we came for, explosive action with a little bit of time in between to get to know the characters. The only issue I have with the plot is that there are a few deus ex machinas sprinkled around. While they’re not huge or even unique, they can be annoying since they characters can suddenly do things that they couldn’t before. The main characters are simply athletic high schoolers so the fact that they can suddenly surpass their physical limits, if only for a moment, is completely contrived


Art 8/10:

The art works for the series. Unlike other shonen, there isn’t a lot of emphasis on special effects so the animation is pretty simple. The characters are drawn with adequate detail and their uniforms look like they could be actual basketball gear. The CGI hoop is a little trippy but the ball goes through it organically.


Sound 10/10:

This is admittedly my favorite part of the show, the music is wonderfully done. During games the amazing soundtrack is used to flesh out the drama of the moment. Episodes where the characters are getting into wacky shenanigans are made genuine by the music playing in the background. Emotional moments have even more weight to them and cleverly placed songs from the ost can make standing around talking seem like the heaviest, coolest thing happening.


Characters 9/10

The characters in Kuroko No Basuke don’t feel like they have a specific role in the show. Of course they fit into certain archetypes but their personality doesn’t rely on this to define their personality. Over the course of the season we see many characters mature and grow. Of course, this mostly relates to Kuroko, Kagami, and all the other first year main characters. However, it also allows us to gain insight on the cast that support them. Also, we see the characters grow and interact in the context of a basketball anime. Their major points of character development revolve around matches and their aftermath. None of the characters truly feel static and we see most of them mature in some fashion as we see them play more basketball. However, the strength of the characters is the fact that none of Seirin’s opponents as presented as evil, they’re simply players Seirin has to defeat. Although ideology may clash between Kuroko, Kagami, and the GOM, it doesn’t change the fact that this is still a basketball anime. This detail captures the diversity yet uniformity of sports: everyone has a different motivation for playing but the end result is to win.


Enjoyment 10/10:

It’s hard to find a show that not only fits a niche, but works well within that niche rather than trying to expand it in an attempt to feign profoundness. This anime is one of those rare types that makes you fall in love with a simple and straightforward premise. Its fast paced and always manages to keep you entertained which is what I liked to see in an anime about a sport as dynamic as basketball.


Overall 9/10:

Overall, this anime is a well crafted joyride. It fulfills the need for action while also giving us colorful characters. However, I  refrained from giving it a 10/10 because of one reason: the context and the delivery. People that watch and play basketball on a regular basis understand that this show heavily romanticizes the sport rather than faithfully portraying it. Of course, the appeal of these flashy dunks, passes, and blocks is also what brings the audience. Despite this, the show offers very little to teach viewers to appreciate basketball. I would have loved KNB even more had the show made an attempt to get the reader in love with real basketball while still enjoying the action. However, the plot is so straightforward that it never feels like we grow alongside the story, we’re just watching NBA games with nothing but crazy dunks, passes, three pointers, and blocks alongside interesting characters. Despite this, the show possesses exceptional ability to entertain and I would recommend it to anyone.

Kuroko No Basket Anime Review

By: Tadatoshi Fujimaki

April 15, 2019


Overall: 10/10


Plot: 10


Sports Anime genre have only one path to take, tournaments. Participating individually or by teaming up, it is the most common plot that exist. While this is not a unique one, it will be the author's capability how he manage to capture the interest of the viewer and excite them. This series focuses on students who love playing basketball. At first, I am really not interested on watching this anime. It is kind of absurd to think of a basketball story with extraordinary skills. But after trying it out, it made me realize that the plot of the story is great. I love the simplicity of it. The main reason of why the series moves forward and how it affects every branches of the story. Unrealistic as it may seem, the lesson is still there. The creator successfully stress out the core value when playing basketball. What also made me hook on this series is the directness of every plays all of the basketball teams have. Each play only last for an average of 5 to 6 episodes. Flashbacks are there but its only on a really minimum basis. You can enjoy watching all of the plays without so much cliffhanging and annoying side stories of the characters. 


Characters: 10


It is already a known that almost all of the characters on this series are super cool. It is the reason why most of the girl watched it, I think. Aside from that fact, the development of the characters can totally be seen along the story. The changes and realization they made make them more of a human. Though not skillfully speaking. Since there are so many characters, giving all of them the spotlight is hard. And that's whats amazing. The creator successfully introduce a past where most of the characters belong. That way, it won't be hard tackling each of the characters past and it gives the story more time in other scenarios that needs to be displayed. I love how the story never depend on the back story of the characters so much that it will take too much time to explain it. 


Sound and Animation: 10


Perfect. My phone is full of Kises' picture. Yes, every character is so handsome but it is not only this. The animation of the story is really great. Parts where the characters show dribbling, passing, shooting or even guarding their opponents is really detailed. I love how they show the movements of the characters playing on the court, as well as their expression depending on the feeling they have. Should I also mention the voices? Yes, theirs are really cool and perfectly matches the looks of the characters.


Enjoyment: 10


I am not really a fan of basketball. I do not hate it, but I do not also like it. This is the first anime basketball which got me hooked. Due to so much enjoyment watching it, I've finished it in a more faster time than the other series I tried. Every episode will make you want more, more plays, more actions on the court, more characters to encounter with. It is really exciting, and fun to watch. 


Ending: 10


This is the best route to take for an ending on this series. The main goal of Kuroko has been met after winning the nationals with his team. But no, the story did not really move forward just because they had to win. It is because he had to bring back his loss previously. He had to bring back all of the people precious to him and he did. Fixing things that is broken and making them realize the most important thing when doing the thing they love. I am content with the ending of this series. It is simple, yet it will made you realize something important.

A great anime for people who don't really know much about or follow basketball. Still a good one for those who do
Positive: This anime is a lot more accessible than I initially thought it would be for being about a specific sport. The characters are interesting and unique and the pace of their development is great. They manage to inject a shounen kind of element into a team sport is pretty cool as well. I think most people would find it enjoyable.
Negative: If you know anything about basketball and physics, especially the rules of the game you are going to have a hard time suspendingyour disbelief and you are going to need to do it constantly. I don't mean the obviously exaggerated stuff, like kurokos misdirection and lazer passes or that a bunch of 6 foot 1 kids that are 14-15 years old can dunk like nba stars or how they all seem to make almost every shot they take. No, I mean stuff like the impossibility of a high-arc full-court standing pull-up jumper that Midorima can make every time, the allowance of clear double dribbles and traveling (I'm looking at you, Aomine) or how absolutely no other basketball rules are enforced besides contact during the shot (would somebody PLEASE call defensive 3 seconds on Murasakibara!). As a huge basketball fan and daily player I found myself at times screaming at my TV lol.\n\n
Overall: If you won't be too off-put by the negatives the positives make this anime something you will enjoy and it's definitely one you should give a shot anyways, despite the negatives. I'd give it a 7.7 if they allowed a more specific score. The fact they find ways to give every game an interesting and unique aspect/challenge is undeniably impressive and the characters and their development is nicely done as well

Here we have an awesome anime about ninjas playing basket.... wait, no.... well yes.... 
That is, Kuroko no Basket has been widely criticised for the lack of a real depiction of the basketball play. So let's clarify this point from the begining: the truth is that the abilities of all the characters are actually very exagerated and at some points it really feels like you are watching Naruto characters playing a match. So yes, if you are looking for a realistic representation of basketball, this anime might make you laugh hard or even cry at some points, even though the approach that lies behind these"unrealistic skills" is kind of well formulated all the same...


Nevertheless, if you just enjoy stories about team game, endeavor, friendship and personal development, this anime is well worth watching. 


One of the best aspects of Kuroko no Basket is by far its ability to embody the "Let your actions speak for you" concept. The story revolves around Kuroko, a nice boy with a weird skill. Kuroko and his new high-school basketball team have to play against his former team-mates in a number of matches. Each of these opponents has a different personality, different skills and different background to be developed in various arcs thoughout the 3 seasons (not too deeply though). In each encounter, Kuroko's basket style and philosophy affects the percetion these characters have about themselves and the way they relate with the sport, helping them to grow. In my opinion, this and only this, is what makes Kuroko no Basket such an ejoyable story. 


Along the way we meet this fairly charismatic bunch of characters which have pretty well elaborated personalities and it's easy to sympathise with all of them, which becomes a good thing and a bad thing at once. It is a bad thing because during the games it is rather difficult to take sides, since you come to like them all, but it's also a good thing since it makes it the more interesting and it makes you thrill no matter who wins. In addition the seiyuu cast is great and they do all an amazing job performing the particularities of each character. 


Besides, this anime has an interesting soundtrack with highly enjoyable  openings and endings (special mention to ending 2 of 2nd season) as well as awesome character songs performed by the various voice actors, which is not strictly part of the series, but I highly recommend.

It is a story of people with special abilities who face the various challenges they face in life as they meet more special people. The main character Kagami Taiga realized one day that he could not touch the moon. On that fateful day he decided to jump with all his might. As the show progresses, we see astonishing growth as Kagami jumps higher and higher. There comes a point in the anime where we the viewers are all on the ground looking up at the dot in the sky that is Kagami Taiga. Helping Taige we have our shadow ninja Kuroko. Striking from the shadows,he is quickly able to take control of any situation by skillful use of his hands. Together Kagami and Kuroko make a formidable team. 


And they need to be formidable coz they are up against powerful enemies. We have copy ninja Kakas- I mean copy ninja Kise, bulls eye specialist Midorima and Super Saiyen Aomine. 


Kuroko no basuke follows the trials and tribulations of Kagami and Kuroko. Oh and the characters all chill out by playing some basketball on the side, so do not be surprised if this is called a "sports anime by some.

Story: 9/10
I gave the story a 9/10 because it has something quite unique going on about it. Although it isn't a perfectly original storyline it's an interesting one that draws the audience in to watch it. In Shounen animes/mangas, the storyline usually consists of the main protagonist trying to surpass someone or trying to become strong for their own personal reason, in this anime you'll be able find those elements too.

I love the art! It is quite suitable for a Shounen/Sports anime. Very nicely done :) 
Sound: 10/10
The sound effects and etc. aren't as overly excessive or annoying like some action type Shounen orsports/shounen and in fact it was quite nice~ there I gave it a 10.


Character: 9/10


The characters are very well done, I must say. *Patting author of the manga tat has been turned in to anime on the back*. They aren't annoying or hate-able at all. They also have unique talents and strengths that are explored in the anime, I think the characterisation is very good. Also, I've never encountered a character like Kuroko in any other animes that I've seen so it was quite refreshing to see him (and fall in love with his persona) :) 


Enjoyment: 10/10


I truly enjoyed this manga. It made me want to get up and play basketball as well as these guys :p


Overall: 9/9


Therefore, I conclude: if you are into shounen/sports animes about friendship, building friendships with others, overcoming obstacles and getting amazed by the competence of the characters, this is the anime for you! :)

I was actually with the series the whole time and genuinely wanted to know what would happen next. The characters were so good too. I especially think Kuroko is the funniest thing this world has ever been blessed with. I really want him to surprise someone while they're in the toilet or something. His quiet and stabbing lines got me every. Single. Time. I think I almost cried from laughter a few times.\n\n
There wouldn't be a series if something didn't irritate me about it. Kagami. Great character, driven and has a very nice power-balance compared to the others. But.\n
His eyebrows.\n
Holy Jesus, why? Every time they zoomed on his face I wanted to get little scissors and cut the annoying, completely unnecessary little spike from his eyebrows. Just. Shimmy the lil scissors in there and quickly snap it. Or take a knife and gently scrape them off. I'm literally fantasizing about it right now. I get that it adds character, but it just. I can't. \n\n
That being said, I'm going to watch the second season. And desperately continue pretending to ignore those brows that have become my arch nemesis.

Kuroko No Basket, a show that introduces to us the means in character development.  We are introduced to a young, and silent boy named Kuroko.  Amongst the 5 peers on his middle school basketball team, he becomes what fans recognize him as, "a shadow".  The players on his team, who can later be recognized as, "The Generation of Miracles", learn the talent they have, which enables them to surpass anyone in Tokyo.  Knowing of their true, and talented skills, they separate to become even greater at basketball when they are divided into different high schools.  As Kuroko is left tobe known as, "the phantom sixth player", he is determined to make a name for himself amongst those who pushed him aside.  He later joins a basketball team called, "Seirin", which we can later recognize as the protagonist team in the storyline.  As we cheer on Kuroko, and the team Seirin, along with characters we learn to love, such as Kagami, Junpei, & Kiyoshi (along with others on Team Seirin as well), we learn just how each and every character has true purpose, and potential, in order to conquer and overcome the obstacles that they must face against the un-defeated Generation of Miracles.  The show not only shows battles against other teams, but it shows battles against themselves, which gives this story such amazing focus on character development.


The show itself is absolutely fantastic.  It's a high guarantee that if you watch an anime, most of the time it tends to focus off of each and every character they introduce.  Most animes lack this, for when it comes to storyline, chances are the story itself will forget one or two characters in the process.  Kuroko No Basket gives each and every character a significant purpose; this element in the story telling is a key to making a successful anime.  We feel for each and every protagonist, and even when you wouldn't think so, it gives us feelings for antagonists as well.  The story and plot is outstanding, proving it's not just "some typical high school anime with a sports team".  It truly has meaning, and I am proud to say this is one of my favorites of all time.


Thanks for reading, hope to make some more reviews soon!

This anime was in my "planning to watch" list for a while and I finally decided to check it out.
STORY: well, the main plot has been already written, so I won't repeat it. I like sports anime and I've honestly enjoyed this. Of course it is a bit unrealistic: high school basket players doing incredible shots, extreme jumps and faster than light passages? Sure, why not! But in an anime, anything can happen...
The story is exciting, you just wanna watch episode after episode (I watched it all in 2 days): there are moments when the characters are under so much pressure (happens often considering thenumber of games they have to play in such a short time), but there are also hilarious moments (Kuroko's ability to be 'invisible' spurs interesting reactions; the coach and her attempts with cooking, etc...).

This anime shows that (a) it's important to enjoy something with your friends, (b) team work makes you achieve great things, (c) friendships and relationships in general should be based on trust, (d) always do your best and, even if you lose, make a step forward to become a better person (and player).


ART: well, I've seen better, but it's not really bad either.


SOUND: the OP and ED were good, didn't pay much attention to the music during scenes.


CHARACTER: oh boy, where to start? the Generation of Miracles is made of... 'extreme' and 'out of this world' guys; the Seirin Basketball Club is a mix of weird and interesting characters; and then there's Kuroko... The good thing is that, through the story, we see all of them develop and grow up: they improve, relationships change, even the always-almost-invisible Kuroko manages to start showing a different side of himself.


ENJOYMENT: I loved it. This anime got me hooked since episode 1. I've read several comments and other reviews, where the most common criticism was "it's too unrealistic" and "there's too much room for fanservice moments". Honestly, this is an anime, some of the characters are described as "miracles", of course there would be things out of the ordinary. But that didn't stop me from enjoying it.


OVERALL: I honestly recommend it, even to people who are not sports fans. It is funny, there's lot of action, there are sad moments and hilarious situations. Bonus point because there are only a very very few hints about romance (which is good IMO because it's really not important here and it wold have probably turned the anime into something not so enjoyable).


The only down thing about this anime is that the story isn't finished yet (the manga is still ongoing), so there is so much more that is waiting to be shown (which makes me hope for a new season? as soon as more manga chapters come out)

First of all, I think this show is mildly overrated. Secondly, im going to review this anime in comparison to Slam Dunk and I'm doing it this way for two reasons. 1: because this is my review, so I'll put it together however I want And 2: because if you don't like Kuroko no Basket, I'm pretty sure you will like Slam Dunk vice-versa.
Kuroko no Basket is an uninspired and bland anime that hides its flaws in its beautiful art and seemless animations. It's a classic "battle shounen" disguised as a sports anime where all the characters are unstoppable superheroes fighting in a gigantic 3season tournament arc. Rather than having a logical story that flowed well, the writer seemed to always rely on crazy plot devices to drive the story forward. To be honest, I dont mind when the characters are a little unrealistic with the unique abilites like Ippo's extremely over exaggerated dempsey roll or the Tezuka Zone from The Prince of Tennis but KnB takes it to the level of where it's hard to suspend my disbelief. \n
There were way too many times when I watched a scene and then said something like, “Oh, that could never actually happen in basketball.” But the problem isn't that its unrealistic, it's that its not believable. For example: take a show like Psycho Pass or Ergo Proxy. These anime are both crazy and unrealistic sci-fi shows but when I sit down and watch either of them, the writing makes it feel real and believable rather than thinking about how unrealistic it obviously is.\n
  Even though Slam Dunk is a little goofy and older, the story is immersive and makes you feel connected. The characters are well developed and relatable even though it's filled with cliched tropes. Its a little generic in some ways but it still feels very genuine and heartfelt. \n
For what it's worth, I feel like there's always a different show to watch depending on your mindset and KnB could do it for you. However, if you love sports anime and want to watch a timeless show that will stay in your soul forever- Slam Dunk will sate your craving especially if you don't mind some older animations. \n

My problem with Kuroko no Basket is something that seems prevalent in some other sports anime; over dramatics. That is to say that there seem to be a lot of over dramatic points in the anime that happen a lot during each basketball match.  
There are literally multiple scenes in which the characters face some sort of obstacle and say "Oh my God, what are we gonna do!" and then this obstacle is overcome. These obstacles often revolve around someone being taller that the other players, or jumping higher, or moving faster. These obstacles are always overcome by simply having one of the maincharacters suddenly be able to jump higher or move faster. There is little thought to how they can overcome these problems. This wouldn't be so bad if it didn't happen so often in each basketball game and the simplicity of basketball does not help this. Perhaps if these moments were explored in better ways you could make the game more entertaining. 


The worst of the over-dramatics are the numerous points in which they make a big deal about the other team scoring having more points than them; usually only 2 or 4 points ahead. They make such a big deal about this and take the time to dramatically show how bad all of the characters are feeling each time. I don't know much about basket ball but i do know that they often score 50 points or more in each match so this makes it rather annoying to see the momentum of the game stop because the other team is ahead by 2 points. It's hard to get invested in a sports anime that takes every opportunity to make the smallest things more dramatic. 


The art and animation is quite good but it does make it quite hard to distinguish between the good teams and the really good teams. This distinctions is not done so well in this anime, which means that whenever they need to show that a team or player is really good it always ends up with them looking like they have superpowers. 


The story is fine but most of the characters are quite forgettable, which is not something you should have in an anime about a team sport, especially one with only 5 players.

Yes I am Biased But to hell with that !!
I was playing Basketball since I was in a nutsack So naturally when this came out I was fangirling ( yes Boys can fangirl)!! Okay , so it can be a little ridiculous But hey Its an anime so just enjoy ( This shit better than crack!!!!)
Now for the review
Story
There was once an epic team of junior high kids that never lost called The Generation of Miracles.  People only recognize the 5 starts but there was one mystery member the team themselves respected.  That one mystery member is Tetsuya Kuroko, who everyone thinks isinvisible even though he's been standing in front of them the entire time.  Along the way he meets Kagami Taiga who's this big tough guy.  In order to win, they must go through each member of the GoM.  The plot makes you fully invest in your emotions.  It's full of laughs and heart-pounding drama.  The show totally mixes that well.


Animation


It's absolutely great.  The art style is really amazing.  One nice touch that I didn't nottice until late was that each member of the GoM have matching hair color and eye color according to their names.  The way they play is amazing.  Their movements were memorizing and just makes you wish you could do it as well.  If I were to be a bit picky it's this weird little thing that they can run full speed for like a minute and only be half way down the court.  It should take less 10 seconds to go end to end.  Other than that nothing bad.


Sound


Love the openings.  It's full of energy that gets you pumped!  It's what you expect and want to hear in a actiony sports anime.  Every character's voice matches perfectly to their personality.  Kuroko's voice is slow and monotone that it hypnotizes you like the way he plays.  Kagami's voice is loud, strong, and boistrous like him dunking the crap out of people.  Some sound bits I love is the ball going through the hoop.  As a basketball player as well, nothing sounds better than the ball going through nothing but net.  The dunking does sound a bit exagerrated but that's the show in general


Characters


One sign of a good sports anime is that although there's a main character, the entire team gets practically equal time to shine.  While watching, it just wasn't about Kuroko.  Everyone on his team from the bench players to the starters had a good level of importance.  All their personalities are very likeable.  As for the GoM, although they're the main antagonists (villians is a bit too much to call them) they still have quirks you'd just love.  Kise is a feminine heart-throb with some childish wonder.  Midorima is a superstitious bookworm.  Aomine is the awesome badass.


Overall


If you're looking for some epic basketball action, here you go.  It's difficult to talk about Kuroko no Basuke and not talk about something like Slam Dunk.  Slam Dunk preferred great story telling while KnB preferred awesome action.  It's pretty even.  However, Kuroko no Basuke is less realistic because some of the things that're done are just physically impossible.  It's an anime, though!  Of course there should be some awesome weird powers and stuff.  I definitely recommend this show to anyone in general.
