Objectively this is a 7 at best. Subjectively, it's a 8 FOR ME. And here's why.
I couldn't remember the last time I watched a sports anime but was attracted to the Bleach-esque art style. I wanted an anime that didn't take itself too seriously and was fun to watch. That's definitely what I got. Every time I watched an episode, I considered whether I should watch just one more.
Story 7/10
The storyline is interesting with great dynamics everywhere. You have a main character duo who are polar opposites but bond together to achieve their dreams. You have the "generation of miracles" who all have different stylesand teach the main characters new things as they attempt to overcome them. The main character's motivation is well positioned going against conventional advice to form his own style. With such a great set up, we are left with the question - how will he and his partner in crime overcome all of these circumstances? The story progresses well with awesome pacing (you know its awesome when the end credits catch you by surprise). And the basketball games were EPIC. Watching characters reveal new abilities felt great and brought an intensity that I didn't think was possible in sport animes.


The humour too is just up my alley with over the top reactions that are pure fun to watch. Kuroko's placid response to everything, Kagami's bullish, thick headed approach and a female coach whose brutal coaching regime complements her failed attempts to be lady-like in awkward moments. 


Art - 8/10 - I personally thought it was a perfect fit but obviously not "perfection"


Sound - 7/10 The soundtrack helped create a tense and well suited atmosphere for games that went to the edge.


Character - 7/10 - Consider them a duo, and what I like about Kuroko in particular his lack of personality brings out the best in everyone around him. Don't misintepret his lack of expression for a negative. As it makes for great humour.


Enjoyment - 8/10 - I loved it. Epic, intense and competitive. Loving the energy of this.


You will surprised every time Kagami and Kuroko overcome a near impossible battle and the logic behind the main players' techniques are great to observe while not being overpowered like in a lot of shounen cases. The main duo also don't win all the time nor are they overpowered and every time they exert themselves there's always a "catch". These things are important for me who don't want my suspension of disbelief to be stretched soooo far. It becomes very clear how far Kuroko & co have come and have to go, going into Season 2. And that's what I want to see in season 2, more progression. And the development of the other team mates who are mere side characters this season is much needed to build on a great foundation.

[This review is about the whole anime, seasons 1-3]
KUROKO NO BASKET is an epic sports anime I’d definitely recommend to everybody who is into the genre (sports and shonen surely isn’t for everybody) and is looking for a well-realized, fully rounded and visually appealing anime. Next to enthralling matches there is plenty of comedy to light up the mood; the anime had me laughing a lot, especially the later seasons.
I found myself to be quite a fan of sports anime, especially after I watched this one. I discovered it through recommendations of friends, and when looking what to watch next after Free!.
SUMMARY
Kuroko Tetsuya, 16, isquite a success story when it comes down to playing basketball - in middle school he used to be the famous Generation of Miracles’ mysterious phantom 6th man. Now, attending Seirin High School, he joins a new basketball club and soon becomes a valuable member, together with Kagami Taiga, 16, whose style of playing basketball couldn’t be any more different from Kuroko’s. One at a time, team Seirin proves itself in matches against Japan’s strongest basketball players, while hoping to reach their goal of winning the elite Winter Cup.


STORY - 8

I will not lie - the story of Kuroko and his teammates is definitely not the most original. Without spoiling too much, it is easily forseeable who will be the winning team by the end of the 3rd Season, as is mostly the case with sports anime. While I myself did enjoy the story, I also understand the criticism concerning it and do agree that it is not everyone’s cup of tea. But when watching KnB, the fun is more in the ‘how’ when it comes down to winning matches, and the suspense does not fall short during the games.

The main focus is definitely on the players’ unique and well tought out abilities and distinct styles of playing basketball. While some abilities might seem cliché at first (e.g. Copy Cat, predicting the future, etc.), they turn out to prove themselves highly interesting when applied to basketball, are nicely explained, and to me seem logical while being supernatural at the same time. My favorite ones turned out to be Reo Mibuchi’s and Daiki Aomine’s (of course) as they simply impressed me the most, but I also liked Kuroko’s style because I have never heard of anything comparable before.

IN GENERAL - do not expect to be provided with a super original story, but instead focus on the anime’s plenty of other qualities.


CHARACTERS - 10

This is the place where, to me, KnB’s greatest strength lies. The main characters, Kuroko and Kagami, have interesting backstories and are relatable even though one might not be a 16-year-old basketball player (as I myself am not, either). I quickly got into their weird friendship which is developing nicely as the story progresses, and definitely found myself rooting for their self-made teamplay strategies to work out.

The supporting characters do not fall short in this anime, either. In almost every anime I watch, find myself liking the secondary characters more than the actual heroes, and with KnB it is no different - the entire Seirin team won me over within the first season and did not disappoint me once the entire anime. I like their dynamic, friendship and humor.

The other teams’ stories and abilities are equally, if not even more, captivating - every team has their ace (mostly a player from the Generation of Miracles or the Uncrowned Kings) who receives the most attention, but also the supporters get the right amount of spotlight. Many secondary characters have a fully realized backstory which is being introduced and resolved during the progression of the anime; as is often the case in Shonen anime, they all deal in some way with friendship issues. Most touching to me were Kiyoshi Teppei’s and Seijuuro Akashi’s storylines.

As for the character design, I couldn’t have been any more pleased. I’m guilty of adoring Shonen/Seinen anime with as many handsome male and female characters as possible, I just can’t help it. What I found very helpful was the fact that each and every one of the players displayed a distinct feature that made it easy to distinguish them even in the height of the games (e.g. bushy eyebrows, high stockings, etc.). Furthermore, I enjoyed their themes (colors with the GoM, plants for the Uncrowned Kings, etc.) and, of course, their matching hair colors, which might not appeal to everybody as it may come across as predictable (à la spot-the-main-character).

My only criticism is that the illustrator is always very heavy on the shadows (e.g. below the chin), but this is just a minor point on my quite positive list.

IN GENERAL - If you appreciate well-rounded main and secondary characters, interesting backstories and handsome young high school students, this anime is worth giving a try.


ART - 10

I’m sure not everybody will agree with me on the artstyle and animation of this anime. Judging from what I’ve heard of friends that have watched it, the opinions greatly differ. I personally had close to no complaints at all, especially with regard to the 3rd season that aired in 2015 and is technically more advanced than the others. The animation is fluid, generally well done and manages to keep up with the pace of the matches. The artstyle itself I find to be beautiful and totally cute at times. It supports very well the humor and overall mood of the anime. I would describe it as bright, colorful and electronic.


MUSIC - 9

The music of KnB is, like the artstyle and animation as well, absolutely suitable for the anime. It is fast-paced, exciting and quite epic at times; I always like it when the main characters have their own distinct music theme, which was the case in KnB (I especially was drawn to Aomine’s). The genre most frequently used for the soundtracks is techno/electronic, which I think is appropriate, refreshing, and it also works well with the animation and images; however, it might not meet everyone’s taste.

About the openings - I appreciated pretty much all of them, even though I don’t think they’re worth raving about as musical pieces in themselves. I’d rate them average regarding the large discourse of anime openings. I considered the fact that mostly songs of the same band (GRANRODEO) were used as openings successful, as the band’s style is mood-setting and highly suitable for the anime.

However, the song I adore most is Lantana by OLDCODEX, which is the overall 7th ending theme of KnB (or the 3rd of Season 3). I’d recommend listening to it in case you’re into some lovely, melancholy J-Pop.


OVERALL ENJOYMENT - 9

As you can probably guess by now, Kuroko no Basket (and especially the 3rd Season) is one of my favorite anime. There is hardly a thing that I didn’t like about it, but I am certainly not oblivious to the fact that sports anime to begin with, and KnB itself, are not made for everybody. So far I’ve only heard strong opinions about it - people either love it to bits or absolutely hate it, which might be due to the fact that its style, art and music are rather distinct. I for one have watched Kuroko no Basket three times by now as well as all OVA’s and movies, read the anime, and am not tired of it yet. To the contrary. I’m absolutely excited for the KnB Movie Extra Game which is to air in 2017.


Overall, this anime has really paved my way into the realm of sports anime (even though I’ve seen some before) and also got me re-interested in basketball as a form of sport. I learned quite a lot about the technique and rules, which I found rather interesting. I recommend it to everyone who hasn’t seen it yet - no matter if you’re into sports or not - it’s definitely worth checking it out.


SHORT SUMMARY


PROS:                                               CONS:

+ Engaging characters                  - Predictable story

+ Humor / comic relief

+ Interesting character abilities

+ Suspense

+ Artstyle / Animation

Time to put some critic to this anime. I know that an anime who was only aired 2 episodes can't be judged fairly yet, but this is just a reflection of what has happened in those two episodes, and I will throw in a speculation about this show.
Without further ado,read further!
Story:
''Prodigy'' Have you ever encountered this word in an anime? Maybe two? Oh who am I kidding, you are hearing this in pretty much every action/sports shounen. And thus we have the same here.
The story explains itself by talking about a former Basketball team, the team of Teikou Middle School. The regulars of this teamwere prodigy's, and they demolished every other team in a competition, and thus they were named: ''Generation of Miracles''.  When they graduated, the 5 prodigy players went to different schools. There were rumors of the sixth player, yes a fact few known is that a sixth player existed and thus he received the nickname; ''The phantom player''


And this is where our protagonist kicks in. Kuroko, a freshman now attending Seirin High is the phantom player everyone talked about, and he joins the basketball. But he is not the only surprise, a player named Kagami also joins the team.  Kagami is a talented player who spend most of his childhood in the US, and learnt basketball ''from the core''. Together the two of them make a promise to beat Kuroko's teammates.


A pretty simple plot we have thus far, and nothing really special has happened yet.


 Art: 


The art is good, and more detailed then most sports animes. Production I.G. did their best, and you can see it from the way they animated it.



Sound:


The OP and ED soundtracks are good for this anime. They fit in well, and its a kind of rocky Japanese themed song. The OST's so far has been constributing well tot he feeling off the moment, so I am really satisfied with the music score so far. Hyadain sure did a good job so far.



Characters:


So far,t he characters aren't having any depth. We only know something about Kuroko and Kagami so far, but the rest of the team remains blanco. I had expected something more from the second episode, like providing more background. But since is this only the second episode, we can't say anythign conclusive yet.



So far this has been a good anime. It started nicely, but I began it losing its quality a bit in the second episode.

At first I thought i wouldn't like this anime and only tried because I saw that a lot of people had liked it. 
To me the story was great. So great that i wanted tit to keep going, so i even tried reading the manga.
I also loved the charaters. Even though Kuroko seem to be indifferent, that made it more exciting when you saw him mad.
All in all I really loved this anime.

As an avid fan of basketball and anime (though I feel less of the latter since joining this site) this anime has been a thrill to watch from beginning to end. 
It's that unfinished Slam Dunk that we were robbed of as children, Taiga having uncanny resemblance to Sakuragi and nostalgia alone is enough to propel this anime to the top of my favourites lists. 
At beginning we focus on Kagami and Kuroko's abilities/aptitudes, small parts of their history. As we progress through the anime the anticipation of the next "Generation of Miracles" member or even the next play keeps you on the right onthe edge of your seat. We are taken through the ups and downs of a newly formed team as well as the dynamics of team chemistry as opposed to individual play. The traits of every member are revealed slowly throughout, some brief, some with decent back story. \n
Each match becomes more intense and let me just say, that the level of "epic-ness" achieved in the final few episodes was some TTGL level stuff.\n\n
Hope everyone enjoys it as much as I do and hope you might even be inspired to take up basketball because of it.\n

If you're going into this undermining the anime just because it's a sports anime, you better be prepared for a pleasant surprise.  Let me say, Kuroko's Basketball definitely rivals a lot of action anime, and is just as intense in its vaguely similar and unique type of "action."  Therefore, if you like action and fighting... watch it, just give it a try...
There's nothing complex with the story, it's cleanly cut.  Just a group of high schoolers looking to become the best in Japan, though it shows some intricacy time to time with back story, motivations, and determination.  There's nothing too differentwith the character archetypes but the synergy the anime forms between them makes for really inspiring and funny moments that'll make you feel good.  I would also like to point out that there is really no villain in this anime with a few exceptions, which is really unique in that no evil villain is needed to progress the anime. 


Plot elements aside, a main strength of the anime is probably its action.  If you like swords, fighting, magic all that stuff you'll definitely be interested in the "action" scenes in Kuroko's basketball.  Though its not actual fighting, the intensity and flare in which the scenes convey are really entertaining and amazing making you forget the reality that you are watching a basketball anime.  There's not much else to say besides the fact the the action is really good.


My motivations for watching this anime are the intense basketball match scenes, watching the characters progress as players and become stronger while staying determined, and the occasional comic relief and montage episodes that build up to the heart of the story and action.  Watch it, then watch the second season, because the animation definitely gets vamped up and things get more hyped.

Kuroko's basketball was one of the greatest anime that I have ever watched. Great plot, amazing picture quality, cool action, background music that really hypes up the audience to the point that your sitting avidly waiting for the next episode. The first season was definitely amazing. But the second season is lowering the anime from masterpiece to just great. The reason for this is because it is a serious disappointment. The picture quality, although still good, is a far cry from that of the first season. The action, story plot and background music are seriously lacking and I hate how they decided to add unneededgags and provocative parts. It sucks. The show never needed these things and the addition is just ruining the atmosphere. There may still be time to improve the second season to be as great as the first but as it is there will probably not be a second season. My ratings are just of the first season.

I think this series is criticised quite a lot due to its unrealistic nature but honestly it is a shounen anime what else due you expect to see, some diligently hard working players that have no flames coming out of their bodies, That's impossible for this series.
Story: 8 - The Generation of Miracles were five legendary players that played basketball together in the Teiko middle school Basketball Team. But there was a rumour about a phantom 6th player that the five respected. Taiga Kagami came to Seirin High School after returning backfrom America. To give some context, I will be completely honest: I am no sports anime fan, and I watched this because I saw the Anime recommendations of Free! (Yes, that fanservice swimming anime.)
Now that I got that out of the way, I will proceed with my review.
I was very exceptical of KnB from the start; "This is just a childish sports anime" I said, but after getting my hands on it, I gave it a chance, because there must be a reason for it's popularity, right?
Suffice to say, I was blown away.
Where do I start?
Let's start with the story: Kuroko is the Phantom Sixth Man ofthe Generation of Miracles, a bunch of basketball prodigies. He graduates and enters to Seirin High, where he meets Kagami, a tall american guy who is very talented at Basketball, and they bow to be the best players in Japan. 


On the surface, this may seem boring to most people who aren't interested in sports. But as we learn the backstories and motivations, you will start to enjoy it.


The most "shonen" element of the series are the skills used in the matches, such as a team using martial arts movements, Kuroko's ninja passes, a coach that can accurately predict all the movements of the opposing team, and even a guy that can do full court shots. And while some may dislike this, I think it makes the anime more interesting and more accessible to people that aren't basketball fans, such as myself.


By the end, I was clapping and cheering as if I was watching a real match. I've never been a sports fan, but I grew highly attached to the characters.


Ah, the characters. They are, in my opinion, what make the series so enjoyable. They're all likeable, even (or should I say, especially) the foes. They all have their own motivations, unique personalities and development. The focus on the series are Kagami and the Generation of Miracles (at least 4/6 of them, the other 2 appear in the next season and the 22.5 Tip Off OVA).


On the sound, I can give this a 10 with confidence. I never skipped any of the Openings or endings, and the music for the matches was great.


The art was fluid. Just by looking at Aomine's matches, you can see they went into great detail with the Animation. I didn't give this a 10 because it was lacking, but because it wasn't KyoAni's level.


I enjoyed this series through and through, and was pleasantly surprised with how good it was. I cannot recommend it enough.


P.S. If you're looking for slash shipping, there's plenty of material here too.

Overall: This anime is amazing!!! I really loved it. When I first saw this anime flying around I thought Kagami (the guy with red hair) WAS KUROKO!! See, even before watching the anime this guy was invisible.

We are introduced to the Generation of Miracles! Basketball Prodigies, and the Phantom sixth man Kuroko. The journey is outstanding, it really deserved a 10/10 but I had to deduct a point because I felt that the outcome was predictable.But other than that I loved this anime. Art:10/10

Sound:10/10


A Hardcore OST to suit a hardcore anime. The music had me holding my breath in places and cheering them on in places. Flawless.


Characters: 9/10


The characters are amazing. You know almost everyone from every team in this anime. Little is left out. My only problem was there was NO character depth of Kuroko and Kagami, the two MAIN CHARACTERS, and now being in the second season there still is not enough depth. Kuroko was a member of the Generation of miracles, yet his experiences with them are hardly shown and all we know about his experiences are the little snapshots of when Kuroko tells Kagami about each character. This was disappointed as it felt Kuroko wasn't much a part of the Generation of miracles, and it sounds more like he heard of them rather than him playing with them at one point.

Okay so Let me start with telling about myself, I am 15 year old with no interest in basketball at all. I don't like playing, watching, whatever. I also am not a fan of watching sports in general. But when I watched Kuroko No basket i couldn't stop. I have rewatched it multiple times (4 to be exact)
So starting with characters, I just love all the characters. Sure i know that it isn't as realistic and true, but they do an amazing job making it seem real and true and possible. There's a few things Kuroko no Basket really do that pisses me off. I binged this in a day, and the anime started off very strong, but ended up seemingly poorly executed. 
Let's start with the major pros:
The comedic relief, probably the best part of the show, it has a lot of running gags through their characters and use comedy to lighten the mood, without this, the anime would probably completely have flopped and I would have failed to watched the entire season.
The animation is good, after having watched slam dunk it's nice to see some better animating of dribling, shooting and dunking.
The music andsound was well used to set the mood and get you hyped when important events har happening.\n\n
The cons:\n\n
Characters: I have never felt more disconnected from the characters than in this anime. More  or less the whole team Kuroko plays on get's no character development and are just pale and boring. We learn more or less nothing about them, and the bench is even worse. We know nothing of his fellow 1st years and they are never really seen playing. I knew more about the starters on the enemy teams than I did about the bench of the team that I was following for 25 episodes. The miracle generation was almost a shitty joke. On the court they're shitty characters because they are overpowered and in theory impossible to beat, so seeing Kuroko and his team beating them felt meaningless because it was just stupid. Out of the court, they were actually well written characters with good development, aside from Aomine who just doesn't change throughout the season. Kuroko and Kagami do not have much character development either, but it was still enough for me to let it slide.\n
The worst character in this whole season was without a doubt Momoi, I have no idea why she was there, why she was written like she was. She was a meaningless character to me. She was introduced as Kuroko's love interest, but they had no development, no real back story and I still have no idea what the point was of writing her character. Was it so they could at just a little character to the strategist of Touou? I have no idea, maybe it was so they could have a big boobed girl run around for some fan service. It's truly one of the most pointless characters I have seen in an anime. There was no reason what so ever in the first season that she was written like that. \n\n
The basketball itself started out interesting, the concept of Kuroko was amazing because he had very large limits. It made him a little boring but it was interesting to see how he would progress his basketball through practice and games in the season. The problem started after Kise with Midorima. Without spoiling let's just say that Midorima is beyond a little unrealistic, watching him play was just stupid, it's like he has super hero powers and it just falls short because it's so ridiculous, I truly wish they would just have made him highly skilled and not a god/super hero. Kise wasn't that bad in the first game you see him, but the last game you see him play is also just boring and stupid. He also turns into a god/super hero. The only one who's actually just (so far) a VERY highly skilled individual is Aomine, unfortunately he's the least likeable character cause he gets no character development\n\n
The anime ended up falling short for me, it was average and worth a watch if you have noting else, but when there is so much more anime that has way better writing whether sport anime or not I find it foolish to sit down and watch this. I would recommend skipping this unless you just want to watch "cute" guys making stupid plays.

The characters have their own personalities which are developed apart from some side characters. It's a very long anime but you won't stop half way.

The main team is Seirin which is a new school but did quite well in their first year.They get even more talent with first years Kagami Taiga who can jump out the gym and Kuroko Tetsuya the phantom six man of The Generation Of Miracles. Kuroko no Basket is a highly anticipated, highly loved and controversial anime, about basketball. I was rather curious when watching, but my expectations are paid. This anime makes its position in my heart as one of my all-time favorite.
Story 9/10
Kuroko no Basket has 'underdogs to winners' plot often used and recycled in anime, with Seirin as a young basketball team aiming to win the national basketball championship. Yet I still find this anime exciting thanks to its fine writing and flow. Each character has something to contribute to the story, not just the sake of being there. The events and matches flow nicely, feels realisticand not forced. They also balance between the highly adrenaline-pumping matches with some daily life happenings. 


Art 9/10

Bishounen, bishounen with muscles everywhere.. ok let me get back on track.

I like how they make the background for Kuroko no Basket, it is highly detailed. Even the audiences are not just some random blobs. The colors are bright and cheerful, at times gloomy, suitable with the mood of the show. 


The character designs are quite clean and sharp but with personality. I like how they keep the shadings used in the manga for the anime. It gives more energy and feels manly. The animation is fluid, especially in Aomine's movements when playing and the super skills. Close up shots are not just stills with their mouth moving, but along with small gestures we often do in real life (like blinking, shrug) which is very detailed. The matches are exciting, especially with angles that make the best use of composition and the effects. 


Sound 8/10

The opening and ending songs are catchy and fun. Openings are performed by GRANDRODEO (the vocalist being the seiyuu of Himuro) while endings by OLDCODEX (the seiyuu of Takao is a part of the band). The songs are very iconic, pumping your excitement.


The OSTs are cool as well, combining rock electric guitar with some other tunes. While there are no specific theme for the show, I find myself enjoying it and can recall several matches when I heard the song.


Character 10/10

The characters are likable and easy to recognize - especially Kuroko, Kagami and Generation of Miracles with their colorful hairs, also Seirin team members with their personalities and screen time. Many people thought this show is yaoi but the characters are straight!!


I love the character development and bond with each other, how they joke around, get annoyed yet still supporting each other and work together to win. The bond in Seirin team is especially strong, making me root and cheer for them from my seat, then scream with joy and punch my fist to the air when they win a match. The Generation of Miracles at first I thought are very overpowered, but the backstory provided makes me admire their passion for basketball. 


Enjoyment 10/10

I find this anime is really engaging, making you want to watch and watch and watch until finish. Episodes are cut in the right places as cliffhangers makes you squirm and ended up playing the next episode. I cannot stop myself from watching, I ended up doing marathon until the end. 


I am not really fan of basketball as a sport, I can play but just decent, I don't really watch real life games like NBA and such. However, watching Kuroko no Basket makes me pumped up and want to play! That is how much I enjoy it. 



While Kuroko no Basket has some impossible basketball powers like The Zone, Aomine's formless shoot, etc. and may not be realistic to sport fans, I suggest: don't let it hinder you from watching. It is too fun to be missed. I end up reading the manga until now because I'm too curious how the story will progress.


I have also finished the season 2, waiting for the 3rd season!

Kuroko no Basket. I started reading the manga before the anime started to air, i felt that i found something really special. Could not stop reading! the entire story just kept you on edge and you feel the excitement welling up inside.
With that i was hoping the anime wouldn't disappoint and ruin a great title. and it didn't. From the very first episode, almost everything was perfect. The art, action and sound. and I cannot emphasize how much the bgm played a major part in creating the atmosphere whether its excitement, seriousness etc. Credit to the director and sound director.  It is so awesomeand you can feel the adrenaline while watching, i can't remember the last time i felt that when watching an anime. 

On a little downside, i felt the comedy was lacking. It had much more of an impact in the manga. Could've been better in showing Kagami's emotions and reactions.


-minor spoiler?-

Story wise, i'm not crazy over the kuroko disappearing act thou. Thinking that its a supposedly a realistic sports genre, and within a basketball court.. i cant see how a player can 'disppear'/ lose focus on a mark. But oh well thats anime i guess, someone needs to be outstanding. Besides that i love the story. 


Overall - its an awesomeeeee anime and i'm not missing any episode for anything. I really hope the anime can keep going and produce a 2nd season in the future.

About the STORY
The key plot is different from the usual that makes the edge of the series from others. There are also nice explorations on different basketball techniques. It is educational and something that you only get on sports series. It is all nice that the storyline has quite fast pacing but it’s hurting the story of the series. There is not much story or drama on it because of the extremely fast pacing of the storyline. 
About the CHARACTERS
The thing about sports series is there will always be quite the number of characters. There are lots of interesting characters to choose from. Of course,it is given that in sports series there would be arrogant opponents that give more thrill in the story. But, if the fast pacing of the storyline is hurting the story itself, the characters’ development is even more affected. There is almost no time for characters to be explored. 


About KUROKO TETSUYA

One of the original in the series is the protagonist’s character which indeed quite rare for a sports series. It’s really ironic that it is given that protagonists should stand out from the rest of the characters but what if the protagonist’s role in the first place is not to stand out. It’s a first and can be challenging as well but the writer still manage to justify the protagonist role even if it’s primary feature is not to have a presence. The funniest thing is that even with the titular name, Kuroko is almost not exactly the protagonist himself. The center of the plot in the series is more on Kagami. The series features more of the amazing abilities of Kagami. Hence, their tandem is made. Opposite attract; one is expressionless and the other is so expressive, one is cool/calm and the other is hot-headed, one is small and then other is huge. It also just so happens that they are blue and red which is known to be always paired with each other. The light and shadow thing is really perfect to describe these two.


About the ANIMATION

The basketball games are made thrilling and as different as possible. It’s animated nicely with the incorporation of latest graphics. It’s almost believable which basketball fans would still appreciate. The character designs are also well made.


About the ENJOYMENT

It’s quite ironic that the first thing that I like about the series is the fast pacing of the storyline and it just so happens to be what is lacking with Slamdunk which is my only concern with it. However, if Slamdunk was extremely slow with lots of flashbacks, this time it’s extremely fast. You would be surprise that within one episode there’s actually two consecutive important games. There is countless uniqueness in the series which really makes it a refreshing anime experience. With the huge amount of animes of today, even a slight originality in a series always gets my attention immediately. I also like that the series is trying to convey the true meaning of teamwork. It is definitely important in almost all sports particularly in basketball.

This anime is mainly about connections to people and places, it portrays Tetsuya Kuroko as the main character. He is very hard to find because he lacks presence, he is very straight forward, unlike Taiga Kagami who is very decieving and he is a character who usually gets worked up easily. 
This anime is excellent in graphics because even if you don't realize it they are seamlessly done. 
The sound was good but it could have been better given more time, the characters tend to have you on your feet through out this anime. 
And in my opinion it is probably the best sport animeI have seen so far. The games tend to be exaggerated through emotion but very well done. I applaud this anime and I apologise for this review being so short, but if you want to get hooked on a fantastic anime this is it.

Anime Review #1 - Kuroko No Basket
By cBuny
I was never a Sport fan, so I didn't bother watching any Sport genre anime. But this anime was surprisingly entertaining and fun to watch that when I decided to watch I couldn't stop. ( Unfortunately there was only 25 episodes so I finished in 2 days :| )
Story - 9/10
Story is very simple and similar to other Sport anime. It is about a team aiming for the top. There are plot-twists here and there, but the most important thing is that even how simple it is, it is still unique :)
Art - 9/10
If you are a basketballfan, you will see how unrealistic this anime is ( Even if your're not like me you will still notice ). But I realize it is for the best. The unrealistic and flashy art is the key to the enjoyment I was talking about. Without this colorful and exaggerated art, I wouldn't even bother with this anime. So you could say it is the reason why non-sport fans like me are watching this anime.\n\n
Sound - 10/10\n
One word, AMAZING. When they play, the music keeps me hyper and the noises are just simply fantastic. The sounds made me nervous but excited at the same time. Truly amazing.\n\n
Character - 10/10\n
Even this anime, there are so many unique characters. Each character has a special skill or power and different look. Important characters have bright, colorful hair colors, including the Generation of Miracles, Kagami, Kuroko, and the girl with Pink hair ( forgot her name ). When I watched this I wanted to find out all the different skills they have so I keep on watching.\n\n
Enjoyment - 9/10\n
I couldn't stop watching and finished this in 2 days. I really really enjoy this anime and when I got to the last episode I gave Sport anime a try ( Now watching Prince of Tennis ). I will definitely re-watch this Season while waiting for Season 2.\n\n
Overall - 10/10\n
Recommend for everyone even if you don't like Sport. Give this a try and you will find out how exciting and entertaining this anime really is. I think Kuroko no Basket is my #1 Sport anime.

Almost every single sports anime share one same thing: incredible, extraordinary and impossible plays in middle of the game, the kind which you can't recreate in real life even if you tried; the only people that might actually do what is done here by some kids or teenagers are those who are in Guiness' Records. So you can't ask an anime of this type to be realistic in tearms of plays and stuff like that, the only thing that must feel real is the characters and what they go through, and at that Kuroko no Basuket does a wonderful job at that.
I toyed a loton wherever I gave it a 9 or a 10, but in the end the 9 is because sometimes the animes spends too much time explaining what we already know, but that doesn't make it any less great.\n
We're in a world in which Japan is forming wonderful baketball players in high school; there's a bunch of guys who went to the same school and were called "The generation of miracles" because they were unbeatable. Among them there is Kuroko, who seems pretty useless at first, but he is the best at passing and stealing. What I like the best of this idea is that usually the protagonist of a sports anime is so strong that he can actually beat a team by himself; Kuroko can't, instead he makes his team stronger. Basketball is a game played by a team after all, so choosing a lead that actually focus on drawing out the potential of the rest of his teammates is refreshing. The concept is great and the plot revolves (as any other sport anime) in winning tournaments. It's pretty straight forward, but not any less entertaining. Kuroko no basket doesn't need plot twist, only the intensity that each game bring. And why are they so intense? Because of the characters.\n
One thing Kuroko no basket has done right is developing fully realized characters; none of them is flat, all of them have some kind of background that is consistent with their personalities and so they feel more real, we grow to like each of them (and even hate some) and that makes everything dead serious. If you watch a NBA match and your team wins you feel pumped inside and you feel gloom if they lose; the same thing happens here, you have a team you really like and you start feeling the intensity because you want them to succeed, and everything becomes more real even while there are plays that seem oddly unrealistic, but that only makes it more fun! And I think while other sports anime are known for going over the top, Kuroko no basket never goes there, because the lead doesn't have the ability to show off, not even Kagami becomes bothersome as we're quickly shown that the rest of the team is fairly skilled too and so the anime makes good use of not only the 2 leads, but also the supporting characters as well, creating a great and necessary balance.\n
In the end, it's an anime that you can easily get into, that you'll most likely enjoy and get hooked. And even while the final episode leave us halfway through the series (or so), there's a second season announced! So don't hold back thinking that it won't have a proper ending, enjoy it because in the world of sports animes Kuroko no basket is at the top.

If you asked my friends and family, what’s my favorite hobby? What do I like to do more than anything else? Then they’ll tell you “basketball” without a doubt. It’s true, for as long that I remember I have been in love with basketball and I’ve been playing it for 16 years. So, when a friend told me, “hey, there’s this awesome anime about basketball, you should totally check it out.” I was excited. Until I watched it.
This is my review of “Kuroko No Basket” a 2011 anime directed by Shunsuke Tada and produced by studio IG. It is an adaptation of the manga bythe same name written by Tadatoshi Fujimaki. Lets see if this show is an airball or a slam dunk.




Kuroko No Basket is about Kuroko and Taiga Kagami as they both strive to become the best high-school basketball players in japan, Taiga the star and Kuroko, the darkness that makes the star shine even brighter. This darkness is a key attribute of Kuroko, because even on the court defending plays forget he’s even there, paired with his great passing ability makes him a great point guard that sets up Taiga well. Taiga is a dominate athlete who throws down massive dunks every game and is a great defender to boot.


The art style, like the music is plain, it’s not bad but not good either it just gets the job done. My biggest problem with Kuroko no basket, is the basketball. I do like the character’s as Kuroko can be funny at times and they really play as if every game is their last.


Kuroko No Basket falls apart as soon as it hits the hardwood. There are so many things that just plain wrong. My biggest issue are the camera angles that they chose to use during the games, the field of view is so narrow that at most you can see 2-3 plays at one time. Compare that to any television broadcast of a college or professional game where all ten players are visible unless they’re transitioning from offense to defense. This narrow field of view also makes it impossible to see what going on and where the players are at on the court. What’s more infuriating is that none, absolutely none of the teams in this anime run any set plays. No off-ball screens, no pick and rolls, no motion and no zone press, there’s just nothing but players dribbling the ball for 30 seconds at a time. Now I understand that most of the problems during the basketball scenes are due to limited animation budgets and time to create these scenes. But I can’t look past the lack of plays, I can’t look past the lack of help defenders and it absolutely kills me when a player takes five dribbles from the three-point line to the basket and they’re not even in the paint yet. The dunks have no impact due to not having any sound effects and far to often the players take off with incorrect footwork distracting me from something that should be awesome.



There’s a lot of missed opportunities in Kuroko no basket. It would be awesome if teams in the anime mimicked similar styles and plays from actual teams and players. I think it would be awesome to see a team replicate a “horns” set from the Clippers or a Spanish pick and roll like the Rockets run, it would make all the games more fun for fans of NBA basketball.


I don’t think Kuroko no basket is a bad show. I feel like it will be enjoyable to many people, but It just doesn’t do it for me. Younger basketball fans would absolutely love this show. But there’s too many problems that distract me from enjoying this show, thus I wouldn’t recommend this to anyone that takes basketball seriously.

So this is gonna be my first and last review, since I'm not into stuff like that, but i just had to write one for this show, since all the ones I've read don't actually tackle the main issue the anime has - it has almost no connection to basketball whatsoever.
Kuroko no Basket's a decent to very good anime, It basically feels like the most average anime out there to me. And by that, what i mean is, It has so many of those anime clichés. A fiery tall (even though the dude's 190cm which is actually barely tall enough to make a basketball team)dude teams up with a passive regular guy with a mysterious back story. Sounds familiar, doesn't it? The anime itself does nothing new, which doesn't necessarily makes it bad, but It's a fair warning to those who're looking for new and interesting animes to watch. This isn't the anime for you.


Alright, i'll dig in to the biggest problem with the anime that i had. The basketball aspect of it. That was supposed to be the thing that separates it from the other ones, that brings some ingenuity to the show. It doesn't. As a huge basketball fan, and a guy who plays it on the regular, I was immensely disappointed. While watching the show, I couldn't shake the feeling that the creators didn't even try to research what basketball is, how it's played and why it's such a beautiful game. Nobody expected Japanese anime creators to be that familiar with it in the first place, but this was just beyond disappointing. The anime could've been about 10 teens playing dice against eachother and it would've still been exactly the same.

And I promise I'm not being too harsh, I'm not gonna bash on them for repeating the exact same dunk 30 times in the season, or a variety of 3 passes and 2 shots, I get it, a fast paced sport isn't that easy to animate and they didn't want that to be the focal point in the first place.

But come on. In one episode, the protagonist team faces off against a team that's supposed to have the best defense in Tokyo. Apperently they use some sort of martial art training to be that good at it, which is beyond reasonable, but that's not even the main issue. The team is literally doing the worst thing you can on defense - They're overcommiting to their man. Why's that? How does a team beat 5 excelent defenders that stick to you like glue? Well, there's this really simple thing in basketball, called a "screen". I'm not gonna go into any depth to explain what it is, but i promise you, you can't watch an actual basketball game and not see it happen at least 10 times. It's as old as basic as a lay-up.

And again, there are dozens of even worse situations in the show, which obviously come up from the creators lack of basketball knowledge. Another great example would be that Kagami, their tallest guy and center, obviously isn't their center. So the floor spacing makes absolutely no sense. And this is all a consequence of the creators lack of knowledge to what a post-up is. There are 0 post-ups in the show. Again, watch a basketball game. There won't be less then 10 post-ups, i promise.

And, this next example I want to talk about is just beyond me. I don't even know what the hell the creators were doing. In a LOT of the scenes where they're playing a game, and one of the team is on the offense, there's literally an offensive player behind that halfcourt line. Sometimes there's even two. There's two dudes, in a basketball game, just chilling in the backcourt, while the star of the team is handling the ball, even though he's usually the center and has no business of doing that, as the clocks ticking down ( although there's no 24 sec clock in the show either, sometimes the offensive play lasts for about a min or so). Id be shocked if there was ever a case of that happening, or if it ever happens in an actual basketball game.

There's times where the player scores/makes a defensive play, or whatever, and the players just forget that they're on the court playing basketball. By that i mean, they get into deep conversations and such for again, a minute or so, destroying the entire flow of the game.


I want to finish by saying that the characters are alright, the plots not enjoyable even though it's insanely unoriginal, the animation is nice (expect when they're playing basketball, which one would think should've been their main focus), so it's not a bad show. Just stay away from it if you're searching for a show about basketball. Or even if you'd like a show where basketballs a small part of it. This has got nothing to with it, other then the general clichés that apply to all sports (teamwork beats talent, never give up, work hard and you'll be rewarded etc.).

On the other hand, if you don't care about basketball, and just want a decent anime with familiar content within it, give it a go, it's a pretty decent anime by those standards.


Overall grade: Average (5/10)

This anime was pretty great. It was surprisingly well-paced and remained focused. The games were very engaging and hooked me for multiple episodes. The characters are generic but unless its Ping Pong: The Animation, I can't see how they could not be in a sports anime. I still found them fun and didn't dislike any of them. I had a lot of fun with this anime not just from the games but from the overall story. The ending game was fantastic and got me pumped for more. A lot of the times, it does feel less like basketball and more like Dragonball z, especially nearthe end, but this isn't an anime to criticize for realism. \n\n
Enjoyment Level: 8/10

I really recommend watching KuroBase to everyone and hope there will be a second season soon.

REVIEW WITH NO SPOILERS
This is my first basketball anime... but i have already watched other coletive sport animes. And if you are looking for a technical and innovate anime... forget about it.
The premise is interesting and causes a little curiosity for the viewer... but there are some ridiculous and obvious moments, besides there are predictable characters and situations.
BUT, the anime IS VERY FUN. This is the kind of anime that you watch just for distraction... because technically you will not find anything diferente from the average.
I need to admit that i will see the other seasons because it is a really fun anime (and ithink that you'll have fun even if you're not a basketball fan). That was my impression about Kuroko no Basket!  \n

So let me begin with saying a little about myself. I am in no way connected with basketball, in fact I am normally not that interested in sports. At least that is what I was until I watched this anime. Now this is definetly a sports genre and something that sounds really tough to make interesting. The story is really, really good. I am really impressed with what the mangaka has had to offer. The flow of the whole thing is really good. There places where everything may feel a little rushed but not in major parts. The art is quite good but Iam a little disappointed since there weren't that many specticular views. I mean when you think of basketball you can always do a more interesting point of view here and there. Don't misunderstand me I like the style of the art it's the animators that haven't done that perfection. I am hoping that in the second season we will se a higher quality. The sound is well really good. The first opening is something that I have put in my own playlist. And well when someone plays basketball you really feel like you are part of the game.\n
 Now the characters, oh god the characters. Everyone is so different, everyone has a style, everyone is special. Dear god I can't stress out how good they were made. Individals is what I like seeing in Shonen anime and is what many other like too. They are the base of everything. Art and story can be improved but characters can not be changed that dramatically. Even though this anime doesn't need much improvement to reach perfection. \n
 Needless to say enjoyment was 10/10.
